     <div class=" col-sm-12 clearfix" id="main" role="main">
      <div class="row">
       <article class="post-1962627 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-movies clearfix" id="post-1962627" role="article">
        <div class="col-md-8 story">
         <div class="category ">
          <a href="http://www.mtv.com/news/movies/" title="View all posts in Movies">
           Movies
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="header">
          <span class="headline">
           <h1 class="h1">
            Is Iron Man Coming To ‘Captain America 3′?
           </h1>
          </span>
          <div class="subhead">
           Robert Downey, Jr. is on the verge of signing a deal.
          </div>
         </div>
         <section class="entry-content clearfix">
          <div class="hr">
          </div>
          <span class="byline">
           by
           <span class="author">
            <a href="http://www.mtv.com/news/author/bobbm/" rel="author" title="Posts by Maurice Bobb">
             Maurice Bobb
            </a>
           </span>
           <span class="date">
            6 hours ago
           </span>
          </span>
          <div class="sm4ShareWidget sm4Widget" data-contenturi="id::mgid:wordpress:post:articles.mtv.com:1962627::og::http://www.mtv.com/news/1962627/robert-downey-jr-captain-america-3/" data-widget="postShare">
          </div>
          <p>
           Iron Man and Captain America back together again? Marvel fans should start getting their hopes up immediately.
          </p>
          <p>
           According to
           <em>
            <a href="http://variety.com/2014/film/news/robert-downey-jr-to-join-captain-america-3-exclusive-1201312229/">
             Variety
            </a>
           </em>
           , Robert Downey, Jr., the man who brought billionaire playboy Tony Stark to life on the big screen, is nearing a deal to join the cast of
           <a href="http://www.mtv.com/news/1913366/winter-soldier-captain-america-3-role/">
            “Captain America 3.”
           </a>
          </p>
          <p>
           Should the deal go through, it’s likely that he and Chris Evans’ first Avenger will bring the fabled Civil War storyline to the silver screen, opening up a new phase of Marvel Studios’ blockbusters to the already extremely profitable lineup.
          </p>
          <p>
           <center>
            <div class="photo">
             <img alt="Robert Downey Jr." class=" js-srcset-img shortcode-image portrait" src="http://mtv.mtvnimages.com/uri/mgid:file:http:shared:public.articles.mtv.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/rdj.jpg?quality=0.85&amp;width=480&amp;maxdimension=2000" srcsetw="http://mtv.mtvnimages.com/uri/mgid:file:http:shared:public.articles.mtv.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/rdj.jpg?quality=0.8&amp;width=481&amp;maxdimension=2000 481w, http://mtv.mtvnimages.com/uri/mgid:file:http:shared:public.articles.mtv.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/rdj.jpg?quality=0.8&amp;width=660&amp;maxdimension=2000 660w, http://mtv.mtvnimages.com/uri/mgid:file:http:shared:public.articles.mtv.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/rdj.jpg?quality=0.8&amp;width=768&amp;maxdimension=2000 768w, http://mtv.mtvnimages.com/uri/mgid:file:http:shared:public.articles.mtv.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/rdj.jpg?quality=0.8&amp;width=980&amp;maxdimension=2000 980w, http://mtv.mtvnimages.com/uri/mgid:file:http:shared:public.articles.mtv.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/rdj.jpg?quality=0.8&amp;width=1200&amp;maxdimension=2000 1200w" title=""/>
             <span class="photocredit">
              Getty Images
             </span>
            </div>
           </center>
          </p>
          <p>
           The plot will reportedly center on the Stark Industries genius feuding with Steve Rogers over the controversial Superhero Registration Act, which forces anyone with superhuman abilities to report their identity to the United States government in order to police the public for federal authorities.
          </p>
          <p>
           Stark is onboard, but the kid from Brooklyn is not, citing fears that the Act criminalizes people like him if they don’t sign up. The storyline would therefore make Stark the de facto villain of the film.
          </p>
          <p>
           In addition to Iron Man turning heel, Frank Grillo will likely return as Crossbones.
          </p>
          <p>
           “I can’t divulge who is going to be in the film, but I think fans are going to freak out when they hear about it,” Anthony Russo, who directed
           <a href="http://www.mtv.com/news/1725608/the-cast-of-captain-america-the-winter-soldier-plays-would-you-rather/" target="_blank">
            “Captain America: The Winter Soldier”
           </a>
           with brother, Joe,
           <a href="http://www.movies.com/movie-news/39captain-america-339-codirector-anthony-russo-says-quotfans-are-going-to-freak-outquot/16640">
            told Movies.com last month
           </a>
           .
          </p>
          <p>
           <center>
            <div class="photo">
             <img alt="Captain America" class=" js-srcset-img shortcode-image " src="http://mtv.mtvnimages.com/uri/mgid:file:http:shared:public.articles.mtv.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/cap.jpg?quality=0.85&amp;width=480&amp;maxdimension=2000" srcsetw="http://mtv.mtvnimages.com/uri/mgid:file:http:shared:public.articles.mtv.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/cap.jpg?quality=0.8&amp;width=481&amp;maxdimension=2000 481w, http://mtv.mtvnimages.com/uri/mgid:file:http:shared:public.articles.mtv.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/cap.jpg?quality=0.8&amp;width=660&amp;maxdimension=2000 660w, http://mtv.mtvnimages.com/uri/mgid:file:http:shared:public.articles.mtv.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/cap.jpg?quality=0.8&amp;width=768&amp;maxdimension=2000 768w, http://mtv.mtvnimages.com/uri/mgid:file:http:shared:public.articles.mtv.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/cap.jpg?quality=0.8&amp;width=980&amp;maxdimension=2000 980w, http://mtv.mtvnimages.com/uri/mgid:file:http:shared:public.articles.mtv.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/cap.jpg?quality=0.8&amp;width=1200&amp;maxdimension=2000 1200w" title="cap"/>
             <span class="photocredit">
              Marvel
             </span>
            </div>
           </center>
          </p>
          <p>
           Surprisingly, Downey, who is already locked in to bring his beloved character to
           <a href="http://www.mtv.com/news/1958351/avengers-age-of-ultron-toys/" target="_blank">
            “The Avengers: Age of Ultron”
           </a>
           and
           <a href="http://www.mtv.com/news/1722881/joss-whedon-avengers-3/" target="_blank">
            “The Avengers 3,”
           </a>
           was almost written out of the movie altogether due to stalled negotiations between the actor and studio.
          </p>
          <p>
           Thankfully, though, it seems like they are working it out.
          </p>
          <p>
           “Captain America 3” is set to begin production this coming spring for a May 6, 2016 release date.
          </p>
          <!-- SimpleReach Analytics Plugin Version: {$SRANALYTICS_PLUGIN_VERSION} -->
          <script id="simplereach-analytics-tag" type="text/javascript">

          </script>

            </a>

          </div>
         </section>

padding: 0 10px 2px 0;
}
body.category #main .trending-list .meta-wrap {
padding: 8px 3px 10px 5px;
}
}
             </style>
             <style>
              li[data-tagid="30"], li[data-tagid="29"] { 
    display:none !important;
}

             </style>
            </div>
           </li>

  <script type="text/javascript">
   com.mtvn.wordpress.plugins.VMNCodaConductor.registerPreInitCallback(function() {
		var click_events = [{
	"selector":"body.home #main article.post .item",
	"params" :{
		"type": "internal",
		"callback" : postClickCallback
	}
},
{
	"selector": "body.home #main .trending-list .item",
	"params" : {
		"type"     : "internal",
		"callback" : function(evt, target) {
			var $container = $(target).closest('.interstitial');
			var category = $container.children("h2").text().replace("trending in ", "").replace(/\s+/g, "-").toLowerCase();
			var position = $(target).closest(".row").prevAll().length + 1;
			return "NewsFeed:trending:"+category+":"+position;
		}
	}
},
{
	"selector": "aside.sidebar .trending-list .item",
	"params" : {
		"type"     : "internal",
		"callback" : function(evt, target) {
			var position       = $(target).closest(".row").prevAll().length + 1;
			var label          = "";
			var category_label = "";
			var section_label  = "";

			if ($("body").hasClass("home"))
			{
				section_label = "NewsMain:";
			}
			else if ($("body").hasClass("single"))
			{
				section_label = "NewsArticle:";
			}
			else if ($("body").hasClass("category"))
			{
				section_label = "NewsCategory:";
			}

			if ($(target).hasClass("category") || $(target).parent().hasClass("category"))
			{
				category_label = $(target).text()+":";
			}

			label = section_label+"trending:"+category_label+position;
			return label;
		}
	}
},
{
	"selector":"body.category #main article.post .item",
	"params" :{
		"type": "internal",
		"callback" : postClickCallback
	}
},
{
	"selector":"body.category nav.wp-prev-next",
	"params" :{
		"type": "internal",
		"callback" : function(evt, target) {
			return 'CategoryFeed:show_more_stories';
		}
	}
},
{
	"selector":"body.home nav.wp-prev-next",
	"params" :{
		"type": "internal",
		"callback" : function(evt, target) {
			return 'NewsFeed:show_more_stories';
		}
	}
},

];

var i;
for (i = 0; i < click_events.length; i++)
{
	com.mtvn.wordpress.plugins.VMNCodaConductor.registerClickEvent(click_events[i]);
}

function postClickCallback (evt, target)
{
	//it's a category click
	if ($(target).closest(".category").length > 0)
	{
		return "NewsFeed:"+$(target).text();
	}
	else
	{
		//finding the main post container.
		var $post  = $(target).closest("article").parent();
		var $media = $post.find(".item");

		var position;
		//we calculate the relative position of the post, within its group.
		var relative_position = parseInt($post.attr("class").match(/post-\d+/)[0].replace('post-', ''), 10);

		//if it was loaded dynamically by ajax, we calculate how many post were before and add the relative position.
		var ajax_classes = $post.parent().attr("class").match(/mtvn-ajax-placeholder-\d+/);
		if (ajax_classes !== null)
		{
			var post_per_page = $post.parent().parent().children(".post").length;
			var ajax_count = parseInt(ajax_classes[0].replace('mtvn-ajax-placeholder-', ''), 10);
			position = (ajax_count - 1) * post_per_page + relative_position;
		}
		else
		{
			position = relative_position;
		}

		//selectiong the size
		var size = getSize($media);

		if ($("body").hasClass("home"))
		{
			section = "NewsFeed:";
		}
		else
		{
			section = "CategoryFeed:";
		}

		return section+position+":"+size;
	}
}

function getSize($media)
{
	var size;

	if ($media.hasClass("item-md"))
	{
		size = "medium";
	}
	else if ($media.hasClass("item-sm"))
	{
		size = "small";
	}
	else if ($media.hasClass("item-lg"))
	{
		size = "large";
	}
	else if ($media.hasClass("postcard-left") || $media.hasClass("postcard-right"))
	{
		size = "small";
	}

	return size;
}

	});

	com.mtvn.wordpress.plugins.VMNCodaConductor.registerPostInitCallback(function() {
			});
  </script>
  <script id="D3FCFFFF0002D51D0002FFFFFCD3" src="http://widgets4.flux.com/Core?includeJQuery=false" type="text/javascript">
  </script>

</body>

    <h1 class="post-title entry-title">
     Robert Downey Jr. Suiting Up As Iron Man For ‘Captain America 3′
    </h1>
    <div class="post-author-time">
     <div class="gravatars">
      <img alt="jyamato" class="attachment-author-gravatar wp-post-image" height="76" src="http://pmcdeadline2.files.wordpress.com/2014/06/jyamato.png?w=56&amp;h=76&amp;crop=1" width="56"/>
     </div>
     <div class="author-info ">
      <span class="byline">
       by
       <a class="name" href="http://deadline.com/author/jyamato/" rel="author" title="Posts by Jen Yamato">
        Jen Yamato
       </a>
       <div class="clear">
       </div>
      </span>
      <time class="date-published updated">
       October 13, 2014 6:40pm
      </time>
      <div class="clear">
      </div>
      <div class="counters">
       <div class="twitter" data-http-permalink="http://deadline.com/2014/10/robert-downey-jr-iron-man-captain-america-3-850739/" data-permalink="http://deadline.com/2014/10/robert-downey-jr-iron-man-captain-america-3-850739/">

    <div id="content-wrapper">
     <article class="post-850739 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-movies category-news tag-captain-america-3 tag-iron-man-4 tag-marvel tag-robert-downey-jr">
      <div class="main-article-thumbnail-wrapper desktop ">
       <img alt="Tony Stark Iron Man" class="attachment-main-article-thumb wp-post-image" height="299" src="http://pmcdeadline2.files.wordpress.com/2014/09/tony-stark-iron-man.jpg?w=446&amp;h=299&amp;crop=1" width="446"/>
      </div>
      <div class="tags thumb">
       <ul>
        <li>
         <a href="http://deadline.com/v/film/">
          Film
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="http://deadline.com/category/movies/">
          Movies
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="http://deadline.com/category/news/">
          News
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="http://deadline.com/tag/captain-america-3/">
          Captain America 3
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="http://deadline.com/tag/iron-man-4/">
          Iron Man 4
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="http://deadline.com/tag/marvel/">
          Marvel
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="http://deadline.com/tag/robert-downey-jr/">
          Robert Downey Jr.
         </a>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <div class="clear">
      </div>
      <div id="main-content-wrapper">
       <div class="post-content">
        <p>
         It looked like Robert Downey Jr was heading toward suiting up to do a stand-alone
         <em>
          <a data-tag="iron-man-4" href="http://deadline.com/tag/iron-man-4/" id="auto-tag_iron-man-4">
           Iron Man 4
          </a>
         </em>
         for
         <a data-tag="marvel" href="http://deadline.com/tag/marvel/" id="auto-tag_marvel">
          Marvel
         </a>
         , but he might be stopping into other people’s superhero movies instead. Downey now is headed for
         <em>
          <a data-tag="captain-america-3" href="http://deadline.com/tag/captain-america-3/" id="auto-tag_captain-america-3">
           Captain America 3
          </a>
         </em>
         , in addition to reprising his Tony Stark/Iron Man role in the next two
         <em>
          Avengers
         </em>
         sequels. Downey — who is onscreen opposite Robert Duvall in
         <em>
          The Judge
         </em>
         , which opened Friday — also has other projects lined up for himself, including the one-time Steve McQueen vehicle
         <em>
          Yucatan
         </em>
         .
         <div class="related-article" data-event-tracking="view,article-post,related-link-module,view">
          <div class="pad">
           <a class="related" data-event-tracking="click,article-post,related-link-module,click" href="http://deadline.com/2014/10/robert-downey-jr-qa-the-judge-iron-man-4-mel-gibson-845359/" title="Related Article">
            Related
           </a>
           <div class="article">
            <a data-event-tracking="click,article-post,related-link-module,click" href="http://deadline.com/2014/10/robert-downey-jr-qa-the-judge-iron-man-4-mel-gibson-845359/" title="Related Article">
             Robert Downey Jr Q&amp;A: Yes To 'Iron Man 4' - If Mel Gibson Directs It
            </a>
           </div>
           <div class="clear">
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </p>
        <p>
         <img alt="Marvel Civil War" class="alignright size-dl-vertical wp-image-850746" height="224" src="https://pmcdeadline2.files.wordpress.com/2014/10/civil-war.jpg?w=151&amp;h=224&amp;crop=1" width="151">
          The move injects one of the most popular characters in movies into a third Marvel franchise. Marvel declined comment, but the comic book corporation today teased the summer 2015 return of its
          <em>
           Civil War: Iron Man
          </em>
          crossover storyline. Originally released in 2007, the Civil War miniseries pitted billionaire Tony Stark against Captain America aka Steve Rogers in an ethical face-off over the U.S. government’s Superhuman Registration Act, which requires all superpowered individuals to register their powers and report to S.H.I.E.L.D. In Marvel lore, the split rips the superhero community in two as opposing ranks align under Iron Man and Cappy.
         </img>
        </p>
        <p>
         <strong>
          Related:
         </strong>
         <a href="http://deadline.com/2014/04/captain-america-3-release-date-may-6-2016-710794/">
          ‘Captain America 3′ Tugs On ‘Batman-Superman’s Cape With May 6, 2016, Release Date
         </a>
         <section class="recent-comments">
          <div class="sign-in desktop">
           <i class="fa fa-comments">
           </i>
           <h5>
            Recent Comments
           </h5>
           <div class="login-link">
            <div class="link">
             <a href="#comments" title="Comment on this post">
              Add Comment
             </a>
            </div>
            <div class="commenters">
             5 People Commenting
            </div>
           </div>
           <div class="clear">
           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="comment comment1">
           <div class="comment-name">
            WMX
           </div>
           <div class="comment-bullet">

           </div>
           <div class="comment-time">
            6 hours

           <div class="comment-excerpt">

           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="comment comment2">
           <div class="comment-name">
            fogdk@yahoo.com
           </div>
           <div class="comment-bullet">
            <i class="fa-circle fa">
            </i>
           </div>
           <div class="comment-time">
            6 hours
           </div>
           <div class="comment-excerpt">
            Yay!
           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="comment comment3">
           <div class="comment-name">
            TV Writer
           </div>
           <div class="comment-bullet">
            <i class="fa-circle fa">
            </i>
           </div>
           <div class="comment-time">
            6 hours
           </div>
           <div class="comment-excerpt">
            Wait, you're basing this solely on the re-release of a comic book? That's not news. That's a...
           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="clear">
          </div>
         </section>
        </p>
        <p>
         Joe and Anthony Russo, who helmed
         <em>
          Captain America: The Winter Soldier
         </em>
         , are directing
         <em>
          Captain America 3
         </em>
         for a May 6, 2016, release.
        </p>
        <p>
         CAA also declined comment. Variety was first to report.
        </p>
       </div>
      </div>

        <script type="text/javascript">
         var highlander_expando_javascript = function(){
	var input = document.createElement( 'input' ),
	    comment = jQuery( '#comment' );

	if ( 'placeholder' in input ) {
		comment.attr( 'placeholder', jQuery( '.comment-textarea label' ).remove().text() );
	}

	// Expando Mode: start small, then auto-resize on first click + text length
	jQuery( '#comment-form-identity' ).hide();
	jQuery( '#comment-form-subscribe' ).hide();
	jQuery( '#commentform .form-submit' ).hide();

	comment.css( { 'height':'10px' } ).one( 'focus', function() {
		var timer = setInterval( HighlanderComments.resizeCallback, 10 )
		jQuery( this ).animate( { 'height': HighlanderComments.initialHeight } ).delay( 100 ).queue( function(n) { clearInterval( timer ); HighlanderComments.resizeCallback(); n(); } );
		jQuery( '#comment-form-identity' ).slideDown();
		jQuery( '#comment-form-subscribe' ).slideDown();
		jQuery( '#commentform .form-submit' ).slideDown();
	});
}
jQuery(document).ready( highlander_expando_javascript );
        </script>

     <li class="widget-container widget_deadline-more-from-author" id="deadline-more-from-author-2">
      <h3 class="widget-title">
       <span>
        More From Yamato
       </span>
      </h3>
      <!-- More From Author Module -->
      <section class="module-more-from-author" data-event-tracking="view,article-rail,deadline-newsletter-signup,view">
       <ul>
        <li>
         <a data-event-tracking="click,article-rail,deadline-newsletter-signup,click" href="http://deadline.com/2014/10/robert-downey-jr-iron-man-captain-america-3-850739/" rel="nofollow" title="Robert Downey Jr. Suiting Up As Iron Man For ‘Captain America 3′">
          <img alt="Tony Stark Iron Man" class="attachment-more-from-author wp-post-image" height="59" src="http://pmcdeadline2.files.wordpress.com/2014/09/tony-stark-iron-man.jpg?w=91&amp;h=59&amp;crop=1" width="91"/>
          Robert Downey Jr. Suiting Up As Iron Man For 'Captain America 3′
         </a>
         <div class="clear">
         </div>

  <!-- START callback function for onhashchange(when the hash tag in the url gets updated) -->
  <script type="text/javascript">
   function global_urlhashchanged() {
		/**
	 * Track pageview
	 */
	// Build the current domain name
	var tmp_td = document.domain.split('.');
	var tracking_domain = tmp_td[tmp_td.length-2] + "." + tmp_td[tmp_td.length-1];

	// Build the current image
	var imgname = location.hash.replace('#','');

	// Track PV in GA
	try {
		_gaq.push(['_trackPageview', location.pathname + location.hash]);
		_gaq.push(['pmc_ga_account._trackPageview', location.pathname + location.hash]);
	} catch(err) {}


	// Track Comscore
	try {
		setTimeout(function(){ var url = "http" + (/^https:/.test(document.location.href) ? "s" : "") + "://beacon.scorecardresearch.com/scripts/beacon.dll" + "?c1=2&amp;c2=6035310&amp;c3=&amp;c4=&amp;c5=&amp;c6=&amp;c7=" + escape(document.location.href) + "&amp;c8=" + escape(document.title) + "&amp;c9=" + escape(document.referrer) + "&amp;c10=" + escape(screen.width+'x'+screen.height) + "&amp;rn=" + (new Date()).getTime(); var i = new Image(); i.src = url; }, 1);

		COMSCORE.beacon({ c1: "2", c2: "6035310", c3: "", c4: "", c5: "", c6: "", c15: ""});
	} catch(err) {}

	// Track Quantcast
	try {
		_qevents.push([
			{ qacct:"p-0f0nSqEQ_DwA6" }, // Deadline P-code
			{ qacct:"p-31f3D02tYU8zY" } // PMC P-Code
		]);
	} catch(err) {}

	/**
	 * Track pageview end
	 */
}
  </script>

		 *
		 * @Author: Javier Martinez
		 * @Date: Sep 30, 2014
		 **/
		var event_args = {
			key:   "kw",

			jQuery(document).trigger('pmc-gpt-set-targetting', event_args );
		} catch ( ex ) { }
		googletag.pubads().setTargeting( event_args.key, event_args.value );

	googletag.pubads().enableSingleRequest();
	googletag.pubads().collapseEmptyDivs();
	googletag.enableServices();
});

} );

  <script type="text/javascript">
   (function () {
		function loadHorizon() {
			var s = document.createElement('script');
			s.type = 'text/javascript';
			s.async = true;
			s.src = location.protocol + '//ak.sail-horizon.com/horizon/v1.js';
			var x = document.getElementsByTagName('script')[0];
			x.parentNode.insertBefore(s, x);
		}

		loadHorizon();
		window.onload = function () {
			Sailthru.setup({
							domain:'horizon.deadline.com',
						});
		};
	})();
  </script>

   <!-- articlecontent_with_ads_beetween_text_159982_1 . generated by cache. is_resource = '1'; build=20130408-03; cnt = '26'; -->
   <!-- theLocation is US -->
   <div class="container" id="contentEnclosed">
    <div class="col-xs-12 col-sm-12 col-md-8 col-lg-8">
     <article>
      <div id="articleDate">
       By
       <a href="/search/Ayeesha Walsh/Contributor" rel="author">
        Ayeesha Walsh
       </a>
       On
       <time datetime="2014-10-14 06:49:00">
        October 14, 2014
       </time>
      </div>
      <header>
       <h1 id="leadTitle">
        Is Iron Man Joining Captain America 3?
       </h1>
       <p id="leadSubtitle">
        Robert Downey Jr is reportedly about to sign a deal which will see Marvel heroes clash
       </p>
      </header>
      <aside id="socialTools">
       <!--ABOVE ARTICLE BUTTONS-->
       <!-- Go to www.addthis.com/dashboard to customize your tools -->
       <div class="addthis_jumbo_share">
       </div>
       <!--END-->
      </aside>
      <section id="articleContent">
       <span id="intelliTXT">
        <!-- Vibrant intelliTXT -->
        <p>
         <strong>
          If you're a big Marvel fan then the latest developments in the next instalment of Captain America will get you more than a little bit excited. You may need to take a seat before you let this one sink in - rumour has it Iron Man will feature heavily in the third movie.
         </strong>
        </p>
        <div>
         <a href="http://www.entertainmentwise.com/latest/Robert-Downey-Jr/news/147333">
          Robert Downey Jr
         </a>
         is reportedly close to finalising talks that will see his billionaire playboy hero Tony Stark join the cast for the third Captain America movie alongside his Avengers co-star Chris Evans. If the deal is finalised it's thought the fabled Civil War storyline will be brought to life by the duo adding an exciting new phase to Marvel Studios already huge line up.
        </div>
        <div>
         <p>
          According to Variety the plot will focus on Stark Industries founder locking horns with Steve Rogers over the Superhero Registration Act which requires all citizens with superhuman powers to notify the United States Government of their abilities and identity so that they can police the public for federal authorities.
         </p>
         <p>
          <img alt="" src="http://static.entertainmentwise.com/images/543cce8565e75.jpg" style="width:585; height:800;"/>
         </p>
         <p>
          <em>
           Robert Downey Jr is thought to be joining the cast of Captain America 3 (WENN)
          </em>
         </p>
        </div>
        <div>
         Whilst Tony Stark's Iron Man will be all for the move, Steve's Captain America sees it as a way of forcing others like him to sign up or be seen as criminals, leaving the two - who have already been seen to have a frosty relationship in The Avengers - to battle out their differences.
        </div>
        <div>
        </div>
        <div>
         It seems Captain America: The Winter Soldier's Anthony Russo - who directed that instalment alongside his brother Joe - has already hinted at the big news in an interviews with Movies.com last month. He told them:  “I can’t divulge who is going to be in the film, but I think fans are going to freak out when they hear about it."
        </div>
        <div>
        </div>
        <div>
         The next Marvel flick slated for release is Avengers: Age Of Ultron on May 1 2015, with Captain America 3 expected on May 6 2016. Earlier this month Robert confirmed that he will return for Iron Man 4 as long as his Hollywood pal Mel Gibson directs the film.
        </div>
        <div>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Read more here:
          </strong>
         </p>
         <ul style="box-sizing: border-box; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px; list-style-type: none; padding: 5px; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 12px;">
          <li style="box-sizing: border-box; padding-bottom: 5px;">
           <a href="http://www.entertainmentwise.com/news/159969/Matthew-Broderick-Gives-Robert-Downey-Jr-Permission-To-Meet-Up-With-Ex-Girlfriend-Sarah-Jessica-Parker" style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: verdana, arial, helvetica, sans-serif; text-decoration: none; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); border-width: 0px; background: transparent;" target="_blank">
            Matthew Broderick Gives Robert Downey Jr Permission To Meet Up With Ex-Girlfriend Sarah Jessica Parker
           </a>
          </li>
          <li style="box-sizing: border-box; padding-bottom: 5px;">
           <a href="http://www.entertainmentwise.com/news/159693/Robert-Downey-Jr-Confirms-Sherlock-Holmes-3-Is-Happening" style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: verdana, arial, helvetica, sans-serif; text-decoration: none; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); border-width: 0px; background: transparent;" target="_blank">
            Robert Downey Jr Confirms Sherlock Holmes 3 Is Happening
           </a>
          </li>
          <li style="box-sizing: border-box; padding-bottom: 5px;">
           <a href="http://www.entertainmentwise.com/news/159639/Robert-Downey-Jr-Says-There-WILL-NOT-Be-An-Iron-Man-4-Despite-Confirming-News-To-Ellen-DeGeneres" style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: verdana, arial, helvetica, sans-serif; color: rgb(42, 100, 150); border-width: 0px; outline: rgb(0, 0, 0); background: transparent;" target="_blank">
            Robert Downey Jr. Says There WILL NOT Be An Iron Man 4 Despite Confirming News To Ellen DeGeneres
           </a>
          </li>
          <li style="box-sizing: border-box; padding-bottom: 5px;">

           </a>
          </li>

        </div>
       </span>

   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">
    <span dir="auto">
     Iron Man
    </span>
   </h1>
   <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
    <div id="siteSub">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div>
    <div id="contentSub">
    </div>
    <div class="mw-jump" id="jump-to-nav">
     Jump to:
     <a href="#mw-navigation">
      navigation
     </a>
     ,
     <a href="#p-search">
      search
     </a>
    </div>
    <div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en">
     <div class="metadata topicon nopopups" id="protected-icon" style="display:none;right:55px">
      <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Protection_policy#semi" title="This article is semi-protected until November 6, 2014, due to vandalism">
       <img alt="Page semi-protected" data-file-height="128" data-file-width="128" height="20" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Padlock-silver.svg/20px-Padlock-silver.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Padlock-silver.svg/30px-Padlock-silver.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Padlock-silver.svg/40px-Padlock-silver.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote">
      This article is about the fictional superhero.  For other uses, see
      <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Iron_Man_(disambiguation)" title="Iron Man (disambiguation)">
       Iron Man (disambiguation)
      </a>
      .
     </div>
     <table cellspacing="3" class="infobox" style="border-spacing:3px;width:22em;width: 24em; background: #f2f9ff;;">

       </th>

       <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;">

        </a>
        <div>
         <small>
          Promotional art for
          <i>

          </i>

          </a>

      <tr>
       <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;width: 40%;;">
        Abilities
       </th>
       <td>
        <ul>
         <li>
          <a href="/wiki/Genius" title="Genius">
           Genius
          </a>
          -level intellect
         </li>
         <li>
          Highly proficient scientist, engineer, and businessperson
         </li>
         <li>
          Via
          <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man%27s_armor" title="Iron Man's armor">
           powered armored suit
          </a>
          :
          <ul>
           <li>
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Superhuman_strength" title="Superhuman strength">
             Superhuman strength
            </a>
            and
            <a href="/wiki/Toughness" title="Toughness">
             durability
            </a>
           </li>
           <li>
            A
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_comic_book_superpowers#Technopathy" title="List of comic book superpowers">
             cyberpathic
            </a>
            link with a prior version of his powered armored suit
           </li>
           <li>
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_comic_book_superpowers#Flight" title="List of comic book superpowers">
             Supersonic flight at Mach 3
            </a>
           </li>
           <li>
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Energy_blasts" title="Energy blasts">
             Energy repulsors
            </a>
           </li>
           <li>
            <a href="/wiki/Missile" title="Missile">
             Missiles
            </a>
           </li>
           <li>
            Regenerative
            <a href="/wiki/Life_support" title="Life support">
             life support
            </a>
            (sometimes powered by solar power)
           </li>
          </ul>
         </li>
        </ul>
       </td>
      </tr>

          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </td>

     </table>
     <p>
      <b>
       Iron Man
      </b>
      is a fictional
      <a href="/wiki/Comic_book" title="Comic book">
       comic book
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Superhero" title="Superhero">
       superhero
      </a>
      who appears in books published by
      <a href="/wiki/Marvel_Comics" title="Marvel Comics">
       Marvel Comics
      </a>
      . The character was created by writer-editor
      <a href="/wiki/Stan_Lee" title="Stan Lee">
       Stan Lee
      </a>
      , developed by scripter
      <a href="/wiki/Larry_Lieber" title="Larry Lieber">
       Larry Lieber
      </a>
      , and designed by artists
      <a href="/wiki/Don_Heck" title="Don Heck">
       Don Heck
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Jack_Kirby" title="Jack Kirby">
       Jack Kirby
      </a>
      . He made his
      <a href="/wiki/First_appearance" title="First appearance">
       first appearance
      </a>
      in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Tales_of_Suspense" title="Tales of Suspense">
        Tales of Suspense
       </a>
      </i>
      #39 (March 1963).
     </p>
     <p>
      An
      <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">
       American
      </a>
      billionaire
      <a href="/wiki/Playboy_(lifestyle)" title="Playboy (lifestyle)">
       playboy
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Industrialist" title="Industrialist">
       industrialist
      </a>
      , and ingenious
      <a href="/wiki/Engineer" title="Engineer">
       engineer
      </a>
      ,
      <b>
       Tony Stark
      </b>
      suffers a severe chest injury during a kidnapping in which his captors attempt to force him to build a
      <a href="/wiki/Weapon_of_mass_destruction" title="Weapon of mass destruction">
       weapon of mass destruction
      </a>
      . He instead creates a
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man%27s_armor" title="Iron Man's armor">
       powered suit of armor
      </a>
      to save his life and escape captivity. Later, Stark augments his suit with weapons and other technological devices he designed through his company,
      <a href="/wiki/Stark_Industries" title="Stark Industries">
       Stark Industries
      </a>
      . He uses the suit and successive versions to protect the world as Iron Man. Initially, Iron Man was a vehicle for Stan Lee to explore
      <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">
       Cold War
      </a>
      themes, particularly the role of American technology and business in the fight against
      <a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">
       communism
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2014)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      Subsequent re-imaginings of Iron Man have transitioned from Cold War themes to contemporary concerns, such as
      <a href="/wiki/Corporate_crime" title="Corporate crime">
       corporate crime
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Terrorism" title="Terrorism">
       terrorism
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2014)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Throughout most of the character's publication history, Iron Man has been a founding member of the superhero team the
      <a href="/wiki/Avengers_(comics)" title="Avengers (comics)">
       Avengers
      </a>
      and has been featured in several incarnations of his own various comic book series. Iron Man has been adapted for several animated TV shows and films. The character is portrayed by
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_Downey,_Jr." title="Robert Downey, Jr.">
       Robert Downey, Jr.
      </a>
      in the live action film
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_(2008_film)" title="Iron Man (2008 film)">
        Iron Man
       </a>
      </i>
      (2008), which was a critical and box office success. Downey, who received much acclaim for his performance, reprised the role in two
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      sequels and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Avengers_(2012_film)" title="The Avengers (2012 film)">
        The Avengers
       </a>
      </i>
      (2012), and will do so again in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Avengers:_Age_of_Ultron" title="Avengers: Age of Ultron">
        Avengers: Age of Ultron
       </a>
      </i>
      (2015). Iron Man was ranked 12th on IGN's Top 100 Comic Book Heroes in 2011.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-1">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        1
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
     </p>

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Publication_history">
       Publication history
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote boilerplate further">
      Further information:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Iron_Man_titles" title="List of Iron Man titles">
       List of Iron Man titles
      </a>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Premiere">
       Premiere
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Iron Man's
      <a href="/wiki/Marvel_Comics" title="Marvel Comics">
       Marvel Comics
      </a>
      premiere in
      <i>
       Tales of Suspense
      </i>
      #39 was a collaboration among editor and story-plotter
      <a href="/wiki/Stan_Lee" title="Stan Lee">
       Stan Lee
      </a>
      , scripter
      <a href="/wiki/Larry_Lieber" title="Larry Lieber">
       Larry Lieber
      </a>
      , story-artist
      <a href="/wiki/Don_Heck" title="Don Heck">
       Don Heck
      </a>
      , and cover-artist and character-designer
      <a href="/wiki/Jack_Kirby" title="Jack Kirby">
       Jack Kirby
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-2">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        2
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1963, Lee had been toying with the idea of a businessman superhero.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-origins_45_3-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-origins_45-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He wanted to create the "quintessential capitalist", a character that would go against the spirit of the times and Marvel's readership.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Excelsior_160_4-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Excelsior_160-4">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        4
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Lee said,
     </p>
     <blockquote class="templatequote">
      <p>
       I think I gave myself a dare. It was the height of the
       <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">
        Cold War
       </a>
       . The readers, the young readers, if there was one thing they hated, it was war, it was the military....So I got a hero who represented that to the hundredth degree. He was a weapons manufacturer, he was providing weapons for the Army, he was rich, he was an industrialist....I thought it would be fun to take the kind of character that nobody would like, none of our readers would like, and shove him down their throats and make them like him....And he became very popular.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMDVD_5-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-IMDVD-5">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         5
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
     </blockquote>
     <p>
      He set out to make the new character a wealthy, glamorous ladies' man, but one with a secret that would plague and torment him as well.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-origins_46_6-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-origins_46-6">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        6
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Writer
      <a href="/wiki/Gerry_Conway" title="Gerry Conway">
       Gerry Conway
      </a>
      said, "Here you have this character, who on the outside is invulnerable, I mean, just can't be touched, but inside is a wounded figure. Stan made it very much an in-your-face wound, you know, his heart was broken, you know, literally broken. But there's a metaphor going on there. And that's, I think, what made that character interesting."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMDVD_5-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-IMDVD-5">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        5
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Lee based this playboy's looks and personality on
      <a href="/wiki/Howard_Hughes" title="Howard Hughes">
       Howard Hughes
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Maskarticle_7-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Maskarticle-7">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        7
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      explaining, "Howard Hughes was one of the most colorful men of our time. He was an inventor, an adventurer, a multi-billionaire, a ladies' man and finally a nutcase."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8">
       <a href="#cite_note-8">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        8
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      "Without being crazy, he was Howard Hughes," Lee said.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMDVD_5-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-IMDVD-5">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        5
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      While Lee intended to write the story himself,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-origins_46_6-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-origins_46-6">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        6
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      a minor deadline emergency eventually forced him to hand over the premiere issue to Lieber, who fleshed out the story.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-origins_46_6-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-origins_46-6">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        6
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The art was split between Kirby and Heck. "He designed the costume," Heck said of Kirby, "because he was doing the cover. The covers were always done first. But I created the look of the characters, like Tony Stark and his secretary
      <a href="/wiki/Pepper_Potts" title="Pepper Potts">
       Pepper Potts
      </a>
      ."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
       <a href="#cite_note-9">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        9
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Iron Man first appeared in 13- to 18-page stories in
      <i>
       Tales of Suspense,
      </i>
      which featured
      <a href="/wiki/Anthology" title="Anthology">
       anthology
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction" title="Science fiction">
       science fiction
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Supernatural" title="Supernatural">
       supernatural
      </a>
      stories. The character's original costume was a bulky gray armored suit, replaced by a golden version in the second story (issue #40, April 1963). It was redesigned as sleeker, red-and-golden armor in issue #48 (Dec. 1963) by that issue's interior artist,
      <a href="/wiki/Steve_Ditko" title="Steve Ditko">
       Steve Ditko
      </a>
      , although Kirby drew it on the cover. As Heck recalled in 1985, "[T]he second costume, the red and yellow one, was designed by Steve Ditko. I found it easier than drawing that bulky old thing. The earlier design, the robot-looking one, was more Kirbyish."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-featurep18_10-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-featurep18-10">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        10
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In his premiere, Iron Man was an
      <a href="/wiki/Anti-communism" title="Anti-communism">
       anti-communist
      </a>
      hero, defeating various Vietnamese agents. Lee later regretted this early focus.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-origins_45_3-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-origins_45-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nation_11-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Nation-11">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        11
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Throughout the character’s
      <a href="/wiki/Comic_book" title="Comic book">
       comic book
      </a>
      series, technological advancement and
      <a href="/wiki/National_security" title="National security">
       national defense
      </a>
      were constant themes for Iron Man, but later issues developed Stark into a more complex and vulnerable character as they depicted his battle with
      <a href="/wiki/Alcoholism" title="Alcoholism">
       alcoholism
      </a>
      (as in the "
      <a href="/wiki/Demon_in_a_Bottle" title="Demon in a Bottle">
       Demon in a Bottle
      </a>
      " storyline) and other personal difficulties.
     </p>
     <p>
      From issue #59 (Nov. 1964) to its final issue #99 (March 1968), the anthological
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Science-fiction" title="Science-fiction">
       science-fiction
      </a>
      backup stories in
      <i>
       Tales of Suspense
      </i>
      were replaced by a feature starring the superhero
      <a href="/wiki/Captain_America" title="Captain America">
       Captain America
      </a>
      . Lee and Heck introduced several adversaries for the character including the
      <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_(comics)" title="Mandarin (comics)">
       Mandarin
      </a>
      in issue #50 (Feb. 1964),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12">
       <a href="#cite_note-12">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        12
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Widow_(Natalia_Romanova)" title="Black Widow (Natalia Romanova)">
       Black Widow
      </a>
      in #52 (April 1964)
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13">
       <a href="#cite_note-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Hawkeye_(comics)" title="Hawkeye (comics)">
       Hawkeye
      </a>
      five issues later.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
       <a href="#cite_note-14">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        14
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Lee said that "of all the comic books we published at Marvel, we got more fan mail for Iron Man from women, from females, than any other title....We didn't get much fan mail from girls, but whenever we did, the letter was usually addressed to Iron Man."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMDVD_5-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-IMDVD-5">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        5
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Lee and Kirby included Iron Man in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Avengers_(comics)" title="Avengers (comics)">
        The Avengers
       </a>
      </i>
      #1 (Sept. 1963) as a founding member of the superhero team. The character has since appeared in every subsequent volume of the series.
     </p>
     <p>
      Writers have updated the war and locale in which Stark is injured. In the original 1963 story, it was the
      <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">
       Vietnam War
      </a>
      . In the 1990s, it was updated to be the first
      <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">
       Gulf War
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-emerging_pop_15-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-emerging_pop-15">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        15
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and later updated again to be the war in
      <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">
       Afghanistan
      </a>
      . Stark's time with the Asian
      <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">
       Nobel Prize
      </a>
      -winning scientist
      <a href="/wiki/Ho_Yinsen" title="Ho Yinsen">
       Ho Yinsen
      </a>
      is consistent through nearly all incarnations of the Iron Man origin, depicting Stark and Yinsen building the original armor together. One exception is the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Direct-to-DVD" title="Direct-to-DVD">
       direct-to-DVD
      </a>
      animated feature film
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Invincible_Iron_Man_(film)" title="The Invincible Iron Man (film)">
        The Invincible Iron Man
       </a>
      </i>
      , in which the armor Stark uses to escape his captors is not the first Iron Man suit.
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Themes">
       Themes
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      The original
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      title explored
      <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">
       Cold War
      </a>
      themes, as did other
      <a href="/wiki/Stan_Lee" title="Stan Lee">
       Stan Lee
      </a>
      projects in the early years of
      <a href="/wiki/Marvel_Comics" title="Marvel Comics">
       Marvel Comics
      </a>
      . Where
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Fantastic_Four" title="The Fantastic Four">
        The Fantastic Four
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Incredible_Hulk" title="The Incredible Hulk">
        The Incredible Hulk
       </a>
      </i>
      respectively focused on American domestic and government responses to the Communist threat,
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      explored industry's role in the struggle. Tony Stark's real-life model,
      <a href="/wiki/Howard_Hughes" title="Howard Hughes">
       Howard Hughes
      </a>
      , was a significant defense contractor who developed new weapons technologies. Hughes was an icon both of American individualism and of the burdens of fame.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JournalofPopCulture_16-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-JournalofPopCulture-16">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        16
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Historian Robert Genter, in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Journal_of_Popular_Culture" title="The Journal of Popular Culture">
        The Journal of Popular Culture
       </a>
      </i>
      , writes that Tony Stark specifically presents an idealized portrait of the American inventor. Where earlier decades had seen important technological innovations come from famous individuals like
      <a href="/wiki/Nikola_Tesla" title="Nikola Tesla">
       Nikola Tesla
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Edison" title="Thomas Edison">
       Thomas Edison
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Graham_Bell" title="Alexander Graham Bell">
       Alexander Graham Bell
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Wright_brothers" title="Wright brothers">
       Wright brothers
      </a>
      , the 1960s saw new technology, including weapons, being developed mainly by
      <a href="/wiki/Big_Science" title="Big Science">
       corporate research teams
      </a>
      . Little room remained in this environment for the inventor who wanted credit for, and control of, his or her own creations.
     </p>
     <p>
      Issues of entrepreneurial autonomy, government supervision of research, and ultimate loyalty figured prominently in early
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      stories—and all were issues then affecting American scientists and engineers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JournalofPopCulture_16-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-JournalofPopCulture-16">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        16
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Tony Stark, writes Genter, is an inventor who finds motive in his
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emasculated" title="Emasculated">
       emasculation
      </a>
      as an autonomous creative individual. This blow is symbolized by his chest wound, inflicted at the moment he is forced to invent things for the purposes of others. Stark's transformation into Iron Man represents his effort to reclaim his autonomy, and thus his manhood. The character's pursuit of women in bed or in battle, writes Genter, represents another aspect of this effort. The pattern finds parallels in other works of 1960s popular fiction by authors such as "
      <a href="/wiki/Ian_Fleming" title="Ian Fleming">
       Ian Fleming
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mickey_Spillane" title="Mickey Spillane">
       Mickey Spillane
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Norman_Mailer" title="Norman Mailer">
       Norman Mailer
      </a>
      who made unregulated sexuality a form of authenticity."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JournalofPopCulture_16-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-JournalofPopCulture-16">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        16
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="First_series">
       First series
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      After issue #99 (March 1968), the
      <i>
       Tales of Suspense
      </i>
      series was renamed
      <i>
       Captain America
      </i>
      . An Iron Man story appeared in the
      <a href="/wiki/One-shot_(comics)" title="One-shot (comics)">
       one-shot
      </a>
      comic
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_and_Sub-Mariner" title="Iron Man and Sub-Mariner">
        Iron Man and Sub-Mariner
       </a>
      </i>
      (April 1968), before the "Golden Avenger"
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iron_man_spotlight_17-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-iron_man_spotlight-17">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        17
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      made his solo debut with
      <i>
       The Invincible Iron Man
      </i>
      #1 (May 1968).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
       <a href="#cite_note-18">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        18
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The series'
      <a href="/wiki/Indicia_(publishing)" title="Indicia (publishing)">
       indicia
      </a>
      gives its
      <a href="/wiki/Copyright" title="Copyright">
       copyright
      </a>
      title
      <i>
       Iron Man,
      </i>
      while the
      <a href="/wiki/Trademark" title="Trademark">
       trademarked
      </a>
      cover logo of most issues is
      <i>
       The Invincible Iron Man.
      </i>
      Artist
      <a href="/wiki/George_Tuska" title="George Tuska">
       George Tuska
      </a>
      began a decade long association with the character with
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      #5 (Sept. 1968).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
       <a href="#cite_note-19">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        19
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Writer
      <a href="/wiki/Mike_Friedrich" title="Mike Friedrich">
       Mike Friedrich
      </a>
      and artist
      <a href="/wiki/Jim_Starlin" title="Jim Starlin">
       Jim Starlin
      </a>
      's brief collaboration on the
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      series introduced
      <a href="/wiki/Mentor_(A%27lars)" title="Mentor (A'lars)">
       Mentor
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Starfox_(comics)" title="Starfox (comics)">
       Starfox
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Thanos" title="Thanos">
       Thanos
      </a>
      in issue #55 (Feb. 1973).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
       <a href="#cite_note-20">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        20
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Friedrich scripted a
      <a href="/wiki/Metafiction" title="Metafiction">
       metafictional
      </a>
      story in which Iron Man visited the
      <a href="/wiki/San_Diego_Comic-Con_International" title="San Diego Comic-Con International">
       San Diego Comic Convention
      </a>
      and met several Marvel Comics writers and artists.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
       <a href="#cite_note-21">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        21
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He then wrote the multi-issue "War of the Super-Villains" storyline which ran through 1975.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
       <a href="#cite_note-22">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        22
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
       <a href="#cite_note-23">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        23
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
       <a href="#cite_note-24">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        24
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
       <a href="#cite_note-25">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        25
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
       <a href="#cite_note-26">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        26
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Writer
      <a href="/wiki/David_Michelinie" title="David Michelinie">
       David Michelinie
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MichelinieGCD_27-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MichelinieGCD-27">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        27
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      co-plotter/inker
      <a href="/wiki/Bob_Layton" title="Bob Layton">
       Bob Layton
      </a>
      , and penciler
      <a href="/wiki/John_Romita,_Jr." title="John Romita, Jr.">
       John Romita, Jr.
      </a>
      became the creative team on the series with
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      #116 (Nov. 1978). Micheline and Layton established Tony Stark's
      <a href="/wiki/Alcoholism" title="Alcoholism">
       alcoholism
      </a>
      with the story "
      <a href="/wiki/Demon_in_a_Bottle" title="Demon in a Bottle">
       Demon in a Bottle
      </a>
      ", and introduced several supporting characters, including Stark's bodyguard girlfriend
      <a href="/wiki/Bethany_Cabe" title="Bethany Cabe">
       Bethany Cabe
      </a>
      ;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
       <a href="#cite_note-28">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        28
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Stark's personal pilot and confidant James Rhodes, who later became the superhero
      <a href="/wiki/War_Machine" title="War Machine">
       War Machine
      </a>
      ;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
       <a href="#cite_note-29">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        29
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and rival industrialist
      <a href="/wiki/Justin_Hammer" title="Justin Hammer">
       Justin Hammer
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
       <a href="#cite_note-30">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        30
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      who was revealed to be the employer of numerous high-tech armed enemies Iron Man fought over the years. The duo also introduced the concept of Stark's specialized armors
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IronMan142_31-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-IronMan142-31">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        31
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DeFalco202_32-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-DeFalco202-32">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        32
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IronMan152_33-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-IronMan152-33">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        33
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      as he acquired a dangerous vendetta with
      <a href="/wiki/Doctor_Doom" title="Doctor Doom">
       Doctor Doom
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IronMan149_34-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-IronMan149-34">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        34
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IronMan150_35-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-IronMan150-35">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        35
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The team worked together through #154 (Jan. 1982), with Michelinie writing three issues without Layton.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MichelinieGCD_27-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-MichelinieGCD-27">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        27
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Following Michelinie and Layton's departures,
      <a href="/wiki/Dennis_O%27Neil" title="Dennis O'Neil">
       Dennis O'Neil
      </a>
      became the new writer of the series and had Stark relapse into alcoholism. Much of O'Neil's work on this plot thread was based on experiences with alcoholics he knew personally.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
       <a href="#cite_note-36">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        36
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jim Rhodes replaced Stark as Iron Man in issue #169 (April 1983) and wore the armor for the next two years of stories.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DeFalco211_37-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-DeFalco211-37">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        37
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      O'Neil returned Tony Stark to the Iron Man role in issue #200 (Nov. 1985).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
       <a href="#cite_note-38">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        38
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Michelinie and Layton became the creative team once again in issue #215 (Feb. 1987).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MichelinieGCD_27-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-MichelinieGCD-27">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        27
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      They crafted the "
      <a href="/wiki/Armor_Wars" title="Armor Wars">
       Armor Wars
      </a>
      " storyline beginning in #225 (Dec. 1987)
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
       <a href="#cite_note-39">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        39
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      through #231 (June 1988).
      <a href="/wiki/John_Byrne_(comics)" title="John Byrne (comics)">
       John Byrne
      </a>
      and John Romita, Jr. produced a sequel titled "Armor Wars II" in issues #258 (July 1990) to #266 (March 1991). The series had a crossover with the other
      <i>
       Avengers
      </i>
      related titles as part of the "
      <a href="/wiki/Operation:_Galactic_Storm" title="Operation: Galactic Storm">
       Operation: Galactic Storm
      </a>
      " storyline.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
       <a href="#cite_note-40">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        40
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
       <a href="#cite_note-41">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        41
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Later_volumes">
       Later volumes
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      This initial series ended with issue #332 (Sept. 1996). A second volume, written primarily by differing teams of the trio
      <a href="/wiki/Jim_Lee" title="Jim Lee">
       Jim Lee
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Scott_Lobdell" title="Scott Lobdell">
       Scott Lobdell
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Jeph_Loeb" title="Jeph Loeb">
       Jeph Loeb
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Penciler" title="Penciler">
       drawn
      </a>
      primarily by
      <a href="/wiki/Whilce_Portacio" title="Whilce Portacio">
       Whilce Portacio
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Ryan_Benjamin" title="Ryan Benjamin">
       Ryan Benjamin
      </a>
      successively, took place in a
      <a href="/wiki/Parallel_universe_(fiction)" title="Parallel universe (fiction)">
       parallel universe
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
       <a href="#cite_note-42">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        42
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and ran 13 issues (Nov. 1996 - Nov. 1997).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
       <a href="#cite_note-43">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        43
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Volume 3, whose first 25 issues were written by
      <a href="/wiki/Kurt_Busiek" title="Kurt Busiek">
       Kurt Busiek
      </a>
      initially
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
       <a href="#cite_note-44">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        44
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and then by Busiek and
      <a href="/wiki/Roger_Stern" title="Roger Stern">
       Roger Stern
      </a>
      , ran 89 issues (Feb. 1998 - Dec. 2004). Later writers included
      <a href="/wiki/Joe_Quesada" title="Joe Quesada">
       Joe Quesada
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Frank_Tieri_(comics)" title="Frank Tieri (comics)">
       Frank Tieri
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mike_Grell" title="Mike Grell">
       Mike Grell
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/John_Jackson_Miller" title="John Jackson Miller">
       John Jackson Miller
      </a>
      . Issue #41 (June 2001) was additionally numbered #386, reflecting the start of dual numbering starting from the premiere issue of volume one in 1968. The final issue was dual-numbered as #434.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
       <a href="#cite_note-45">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        45
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The next Iron Man series,
      <i>
       The Invincible Iron Man
      </i>
      vol. 4, debuted in early 2005 with the
      <a href="/wiki/Warren_Ellis" title="Warren Ellis">
       Warren Ellis
      </a>
      -written storyline "
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Extremis_(comics)" title="Extremis (comics)">
       Extremis
      </a>
      ", with artist
      <a href="/wiki/Adi_Granov" title="Adi Granov">
       Adi Granov
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46">
       <a href="#cite_note-46">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        46
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
       <a href="#cite_note-47">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        47
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It ran 35 issues (Jan. 2005 - Jan. 2009), with the cover logo simply
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      beginning with issue #13, and
      <i>
       Iron Man: Director of
       <a href="/wiki/S.H.I.E.L.D." title="S.H.I.E.L.D.">
        S.H.I.E.L.D.
       </a>
      </i>
      , beginning issue #15. On the final three issues, the cover logo was overwritten by "War Machine, Weapon of S.H.I.E.L.D.",
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vol4_48-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-vol4-48">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        48
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      which led to the launch of a
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/War_Machine" title="War Machine">
        War Machine
       </a>
      </i>
      ongoing series.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
       <a href="#cite_note-49">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        49
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <i>
       The Invincible Iron Man
      </i>
      vol. 5, by writer
      <a href="/wiki/Matt_Fraction" title="Matt Fraction">
       Matt Fraction
      </a>
      and artist
      <a href="/wiki/Salvador_Larroca" title="Salvador Larroca">
       Salvador Larroca
      </a>
      , began with a premiere issue cover-dated July 2008.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fraction_50-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-fraction-50">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        50
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      For a seven-month overlap, Marvel published both volume four and volume five simultaneously.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vol4_48-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-vol4-48">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        48
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
       <a href="#cite_note-51">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        51
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Volume five jumped its numbering of issues from #33 to #500, cover dated March 2011, to reflect the start from the premiere issue of volume one in 1968.
     </p>
     <p>
      Many Iron Man
      <a href="/wiki/Annual_publication" title="Annual publication">
       annuals
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Miniseries" title="Miniseries">
       miniseries
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/One-shot_(comics)" title="One-shot (comics)">
       one-shot
      </a>
      titles have been published through the years, such as
      <i>
       Age of Innocence: The Rebirth of Iron Man
      </i>
      (Feb. 1996),
      <i>
       Iron Man: The Iron Age
      </i>
      #1-2 (Aug.-Sept. 1998),
      <i>
       Iron Man: Bad Blood
      </i>
      #1-4 (Sept.-Dec. 2000),
      <i>
       Iron Man House of M
      </i>
      #1-3 (Sept.-Nov. 2005),
      <i>
       Fantastic Four / Iron Man: Big in Japan
      </i>
      #1-4 (Dec. 2005 - March 2006),
      <i>
       Iron Man: The Inevitable
      </i>
      #1-6 (Feb.-July 2006),
      <i>
       Iron Man / Captain America: Casualties of War
      </i>
      (Feb. 2007),
      <i>
       Iron Man: Hypervelocity
      </i>
      #1-6 (March-Aug. 2007),
      <i>
       Iron Man: Enter the Mandarin
      </i>
      #1-6 (Nov. 2007 - April 2008), and
      <i>
       Iron Man: Legacy of Doom
      </i>
      (June-Sept. 2008). Publications have included such spin-offs as the one-shot
      <i>
       Iron Man 2020
      </i>
      (June 1994), featuring a different Iron Man in the future, and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Animated_TV_series" title="Animated TV series">
       animated TV series
      </a>
      adaptations
      <i>
       Marvel Action Hour, Featuring Iron Man
      </i>
      #1-8 (Nov. 1994 - June 1995) and
      <i>
       Marvel Adventures Iron Man
      </i>
      #1-12 (July 2007 - June 2008).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
       <a href="#cite_note-52">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        52
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Fictional_character_biography">
       Fictional character biography
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="thumb tleft" style="width: 212px;">
      <div class="thumbinner">
       <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tales_of_Suspense_39.jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="448" data-file-width="300" height="299" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c6/Tales_of_Suspense_39.jpg/200px-Tales_of_Suspense_39.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/c/c6/Tales_of_Suspense_39.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/c/c6/Tales_of_Suspense_39.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         <i>
          Tales of Suspense
         </i>
         #39 (March 1963): Iron Man debuts. Cover art by
         <a href="/wiki/Jack_Kirby" title="Jack Kirby">
          Jack Kirby
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Don_Heck" title="Don Heck">
          Don Heck
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
       <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TalesOfSuspense48.jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="484" data-file-width="329" height="294" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/3/3e/TalesOfSuspense48.jpg/200px-TalesOfSuspense48.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/3/3e/TalesOfSuspense48.jpg/300px-TalesOfSuspense48.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/3/3e/TalesOfSuspense48.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         <i>
          Tales of Suspense
         </i>
         #48 (Dec. 1963), the debut of Iron Man's first red-and-gold suit of armor. Cover art by Jack Kirby and
         <a href="/wiki/Sol_Brodsky" title="Sol Brodsky">
          Sol Brodsky
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Origins">
       Origins
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Anthony Edward Stark, the son of wealthy industrialist and head of
      <a href="/wiki/Stark_Industries" title="Stark Industries">
       Stark Industries
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Howard_Stark" title="Howard Stark">
       Howard Stark
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Maria_Stark" title="Maria Stark">
       Maria Stark
      </a>
      , is born on
      <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">
       Long Island
      </a>
      . A boy genius, he enters
      <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology" title="Massachusetts Institute of Technology">
       MIT
      </a>
      at the age of 15 to study
      <a href="/wiki/Electrical_engineering" title="Electrical engineering">
