       electrical engineering
      </a>
      and later receives Master's degrees in electrical engineering and physics. After his parents are killed in a car accident, he inherits his father's company.
     </p>
     <p>
      Tony Stark is injured by a booby trap and captured by enemy forces led by
      <a href="/wiki/Wong-Chu" title="Wong-Chu">
       Wong-Chu
      </a>
      . Wong-Chu orders Stark to build weapons, but Stark's injuries are dire and shrapnel is moving towards his heart. His fellow prisoner,
      <a href="/wiki/Ho_Yinsen" title="Ho Yinsen">
       Ho Yinsen
      </a>
      , a
      <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">
       Nobel Prize
      </a>
      -winning
      <a href="/wiki/Physicist" title="Physicist">
       physicist
      </a>
      whose work Stark had greatly admired during college, constructs a
      <a href="/wiki/Magnetism" title="Magnetism">
       magnetic
      </a>
      chest plate to keep the shrapnel from reaching Stark's heart, keeping him alive. In secret, Stark and Yinsen use the workshop to design and construct a
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man%27s_armor" title="Iron Man's armor">
       suit
      </a>
      of
      <a href="/wiki/Powered_exoskeleton" title="Powered exoskeleton">
       powered armor
      </a>
      , which Stark uses to escape. But during the escape attempt, Yinsen sacrifices his life to save Stark's by distracting the enemy as Stark recharges. Stark takes revenge on his kidnappers and heads back to rejoin the American forces, on his way meeting a wounded American
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps" title="United States Marine Corps">
       Marine
      </a>
      fighter pilot,
      <a href="/wiki/War_Machine" title="War Machine">
       James "Rhodey" Rhodes
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Back home, Stark discovers that the shrapnel fragment lodged in his chest cannot be removed without killing him, and he is forced to wear the armor's chestplate beneath his clothes to act as a regulator for his heart. He must recharge the chestplate every day or else risk the shrapnel killing him. The cover for Iron Man is that he is Stark's
      <a href="/wiki/Bodyguard" title="Bodyguard">
       bodyguard
      </a>
      and corporate mascot. To that end, Iron Man fights threats to his company, such as
      <a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">
       Communist
      </a>
      opponents
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Widow_(Natalia_Romanova)" title="Black Widow (Natalia Romanova)">
       Black Widow
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Crimson_Dynamo" title="Crimson Dynamo">
       Crimson Dynamo
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Titanium_Man" title="Titanium Man">
       Titanium Man
      </a>
      , as well as independent villains like the
      <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_(comics)" title="Mandarin (comics)">
       Mandarin
      </a>
      , who eventually becomes his greatest enemy. No one suspects Stark of being Iron Man as he cultivates an image as a rich playboy and industrialist. Two notable members of Stark's supporting cast at this point are his personal chauffeur
      <a href="/wiki/Happy_Hogan" title="Happy Hogan">
       Harold "Happy" Hogan
      </a>
      and secretary
      <a href="/wiki/Pepper_Potts" title="Pepper Potts">
       Virginia "Pepper" Potts
      </a>
      , to both of whom he eventually reveals his dual identity. Meanwhile, James Rhodes finds his own niche as Stark's personal pilot, revealing himself to be a man of extraordinary skill and daring.
     </p>
     <p>
      The comic took an anti-Communist stance in its early years, which was softened as opposition rose to the
      <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">
       Vietnam War
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-origins_45_3-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-origins_45-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      This change evolved in a series of stories with Stark profoundly reconsidering his political opinions and the morality of manufacturing weapons for the military. Stark shows himself to be occasionally arrogant and willing to let the ends justify the means.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
       <a href="#cite_note-53">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        53
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
       <a href="#cite_note-54">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        54
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      This leads to personal conflicts with the people around him, both in his civilian and superhero identities. Stark uses his personal fortune not only to outfit his own armor, but also to develop weapons for
      <a href="/wiki/S.H.I.E.L.D." title="S.H.I.E.L.D.">
       S.H.I.E.L.D.
      </a>
      and other technologies such as the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quinjet" title="Quinjet">
       Quinjets
      </a>
      used by the Avengers, and the image inducers used by the
      <a href="/wiki/X-Men" title="X-Men">
       X-Men
      </a>
      . Eventually, Stark's heart condition is discovered by the public and treated with an artificial
      <a href="/wiki/Heart_transplantation" title="Heart transplantation">
       heart transplant
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
       <a href="#cite_note-55">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        55
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="1970s_and_early_1980s">
       1970s and early 1980s
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Later on, Stark expands on his armor designs and begins to build his arsenal of specialized armors for particular situations such as for
      <a href="/wiki/Human_spaceflight" title="Human spaceflight">
       space travel
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IronMan142_31-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-IronMan142-31">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        31
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Stealth_technology" title="Stealth technology">
       stealth
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DeFalco202_32-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-DeFalco202-32">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        32
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IronMan152_33-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-IronMan152-33">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        33
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Stark develops a serious dependency on
      <a href="/wiki/Alcoholism" title="Alcoholism">
       alcohol
      </a>
      in the "
      <a href="/wiki/Demon_in_a_Bottle" title="Demon in a Bottle">
       Demon in a Bottle
      </a>
      " storyline.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
       <a href="#cite_note-56">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        56
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The first time it becomes a problem is when Stark discovers that the national security agency
      <a href="/wiki/S.H.I.E.L.D." title="S.H.I.E.L.D.">
       S.H.I.E.L.D.
      </a>
      has been buying a controlling interest in his company in order to ensure Stark's continued weapons development for them. At the same time, it was revealed that several minor supervillains armed with advanced weapons who had bedeviled Stark throughout his superhero career were in fact in the employ of Stark's business rival,
      <a href="/wiki/Justin_Hammer" title="Justin Hammer">
       Justin Hammer
      </a>
      who began to plague Stark more directly.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
       <a href="#cite_note-57">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        57
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IronMan124_58-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-IronMan124-58">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        58
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      At one point in Hammer's manipulations, the Iron Man armor is even taken over and used to murder a diplomat.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IronMan124_58-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-IronMan124-58">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        58
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Although Iron Man is not immediately under suspicion, Stark is forced to hand the armor over to the authorities.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
       <a href="#cite_note-59">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        59
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Eventually Stark and Rhodes, who is now his personal pilot and confidant, track down and defeat those responsible, although Hammer would return to bedevil Stark again.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IronMan142_31-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-IronMan142-31">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        31
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
       <a href="#cite_note-60">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        60
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      With the support of his then-girlfriend,
      <a href="/wiki/Bethany_Cabe" title="Bethany Cabe">
       Bethany Cabe
      </a>
      , his friends and his employees, Stark pulls through these crises and overcomes his dependency on alcohol.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
       <a href="#cite_note-61">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        61
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Even as he recovers from this harrowing personal trial, Stark's life is further complicated when he has a confrontation with
      <a href="/wiki/Doctor_Doom" title="Doctor Doom">
       Doctor Doom
      </a>
      that is interrupted by an opportunistic enemy sending them back in time to the time of
      <a href="/wiki/King_Arthur" title="King Arthur">
       King Arthur
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IronMan149_34-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-IronMan149-34">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        34
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Once there, Iron Man thwarts Doom's attempt to solicit the aid of
      <a href="/wiki/Morgan_le_Fay_(Marvel_Comics)" title="Morgan le Fay (Marvel Comics)">
       Morgan Le Fay
      </a>
      , and the Latverian ruler swears deadly vengeance - to be indulged sometime after the two return to their own time.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IronMan150_35-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-IronMan150-35">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        35
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      This incident was collected and published as
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Doomquest" title="Doomquest">
        Doomquest
       </a>
       .
      </i>
     </p>
     <p>
      Some time later, a ruthless rival,
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Monger" title="Iron Monger">
       Obadiah Stane
      </a>
      , manipulates Stark emotionally into a serious relapse. As a result, Stark loses control of Stark International to Stane, becomes a homeless alcohol-abusing vagrant and gives up his armored identity to Rhodes, who becomes the new Iron Man for a lengthy period of time. Eventually, Stark recovers and joins a new startup, Circuits Maximus. Stark concentrates on new technological designs, including building a new set of armor as part of his recuperative therapy. Rhodes continues to act as Iron Man but steadily grows more aggressive and paranoid, due to the armor not having been calibrated properly for his use. Eventually Rhodes goes on a rampage, and Stark has to don a replica of his original armor to stop him. Fully recovered, Stark confronts Stane who has himself designed a version of armor based around designs seized along with Stark International, dubbing himself 'Iron Monger'. Defeated in battle, Stane rather than give Stark the satisfaction of taking him to trial, commits suicide.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
       <a href="#cite_note-62">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        62
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Shortly thereafter, Stark regains his personal fortune, but decides against repurchasing Stark International until much later; he instead creates Stark Enterprises, headquartered in
      <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">
       Los Angeles
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Late_1980s_and_1990s">
       Late 1980s and 1990s
      </span>
     </h3>
     <table class="metadata plainlinks ambox ambox-style ambox-Plot" role="presentation">
      <tr>
       <td class="mbox-image">
        <div style="width:52px;">
         <img alt="" data-file-height="48" data-file-width="48" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/40px-Edit-clear.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/60px-Edit-clear.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/80px-Edit-clear.svg.png 2x" width="40"/>
        </div>
       </td>
       <td class="mbox-text">
        <span class="mbox-text-span">
         This article's plot summary
         <b>
          may be
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:How_to_write_a_plot_summary#What_to_cut" title="Wikipedia:How to write a plot summary">
           too long
          </a>
          or
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:How_to_write_a_plot_summary" title="Wikipedia:How to write a plot summary">
           excessively detailed
          </a>
          .
         </b>
         <span class="hide-when-compact">
          Please
          <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iron_Man&amp;action=edit">
           help improve it
          </a>
          by removing unnecessary details and making it more concise.
         </span>
         <small>
          <i>
           (December 2013)
          </i>
         </small>
        </span>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      In an attempt to stop other people from misusing his designs, Stark goes about
      <a href="/wiki/Armor_Wars" title="Armor Wars">
       disabling other armored heroes and villains
      </a>
      who are using suits based on the Iron Man technology, the designs of which were stolen by his enemy
      <a href="/wiki/Spymaster_(comics)#Spymaster_I" title="Spymaster (comics)">
       Spymaster
      </a>
      . His quest to destroy all instances of the stolen technology severely hurts his reputation as Iron Man. After attacking and disabling a series of minor villains such as
      <a href="/wiki/Stilt-Man" title="Stilt-Man">
       Stilt-Man
      </a>
      , he attacks and defeats the government operative known as
      <a href="/wiki/Stingray_(comics)" title="Stingray (comics)">
       Stingray
      </a>
      . The situation worsens when Stark realizes that Stingray's armor does not incorporate any of his designs. He publicly "fires" Iron Man while covertly pursuing his agenda. He uses the cover story of wanting to help disable the rogue Iron Man to infiltrate and disable the armor of the S.H.I.E.L.D. operatives known as the
      <a href="/wiki/Mandroid" title="Mandroid">
       Mandroids
      </a>
      , and disabling the armor of the
      <a href="/wiki/Guardsman_(comics)" title="Guardsman (comics)">
       Guardsmen
      </a>
      , in the process allowing some of the villains that they guard to escape. This leads the
      <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States" title="Federal government of the United States">
       United States government
      </a>
      to declare Iron Man a danger and an outlaw. Iron Man then travels to Russia where he inadvertently causes the death of the Soviet
      <a href="/wiki/Titanium_Man#Titanium_Man_II_-_The_Gremlin" title="Titanium Man">
       Titanium Man
      </a>
      during a fight. Returning to the U.S., he faces an enemy commissioned by the government named
      <a href="/wiki/Firepower_(comics)" title="Firepower (comics)">
       Firepower
      </a>
      . Unable to defeat him head on, Stark fakes Iron Man's demise, intending to retire the suit permanently. When Firepower goes rogue, Stark creates a new suit, claiming that a new person is in the armor.
     </p>
     <p>
      Stark's health continues to deteriorate, and he discovers the armor's
      <a href="/wiki/Cybernetics" title="Cybernetics">
       cybernetic
      </a>
      interface is causing irreversible damage to his
      <a href="/wiki/Nervous_system" title="Nervous system">
       nervous system
      </a>
      . His condition is aggravated by a failed attempt on his life by Kathy Dare, a mentally unbalanced former lover, which injures his spine, paralyzing him. Stark has a nerve chip implanted into his spine to regain his mobility.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
       <a href="#cite_note-63">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        63
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Still, Stark's nervous system continues its slide towards failure, and he constructs a "skin" made up of artificial nerve circuitry to assist it. Stark begins to pilot a remote-controlled Iron Man armor, but when faced with the Masters of Silence, the
      <a href="/wiki/Telepresence" title="Telepresence">
       telepresence
      </a>
      suit proves inadequate. Stark then designs a more heavily armed version of the suit to wear, the "Variable Threat Response Battle Suit", which becomes known as the
      <a href="/wiki/War_Machine" title="War Machine">
       War Machine armor
      </a>
      . Ultimately, the damage to his nervous system becomes too extensive. Faking his death, Stark places himself in
      <a href="/wiki/Suspended_animation" title="Suspended animation">
       suspended animation
      </a>
      to heal as Rhodes takes over both the running of Stark Enterprises and the mantle of Iron Man, although he utilizes the War Machine armor. Stark ultimately makes a full recovery by using a chip to reprogram himself and resumes the Iron Man identity. When Rhodes learns that Stark has manipulated his friends by faking his own death, he becomes enraged and the two friends part ways, Rhodes continuing as War Machine in a solo career.
     </p>
     <p>
      The story arc "The Crossing" reveals Iron Man as a traitor among the Avengers' ranks, due to years of manipulation by the time-traveling dictator
      <a href="/wiki/Kang_the_Conqueror" title="Kang the Conqueror">
       Kang the Conqueror
      </a>
      . Stark, as a sleeper agent in Kang's thrall, kills Marilla, the nanny of
      <a href="/wiki/Crystal_(comics)" title="Crystal (comics)">
       Crystal
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Quicksilver_(comics)" title="Quicksilver (comics)">
       Quicksilver's
      </a>
      daughter Luna, as well as Rita DeMara, the female
      <a href="/wiki/Yellowjacket_(Rita_DeMara)" title="Yellowjacket (Rita DeMara)">
       Yellowjacket
      </a>
      , then Amanda Chaney, an ally of the Avengers. The
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Avengers_Forever" title="Avengers Forever">
        Avengers Forever
       </a>
      </i>
      limited series later
      <a href="/wiki/Retroactive_continuity" title="Retroactive continuity">
       retcons
      </a>
      these events as the work of a disguised
      <a href="/wiki/Immortus" title="Immortus">
       Immortus
      </a>
      , not Kang, and that the mental control had gone back only a few months.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
       <a href="#cite_note-64">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        64
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Needing help to defeat both Stark and the ostensible Kang, the team travels back in time to recruit a teenaged Anthony Stark from an alternate timeline to assist them. The young Stark steals an Iron Man suit in order to aid the Avengers against his older self. The sight of his younger self shocks the older Stark enough for him to regain momentary control of his actions, and he sacrifices his life to stop Kang. The young Stark later builds his own suit to become the new Iron Man, and, remaining in the present day, gains legal control of "his" company.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">
         <span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific volume in which the source appears. (August 2014)">
          volume &amp; issue needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      During the battle with the creature called
      <a href="/wiki/Onslaught_(comics)" title="Onslaught (comics)">
       Onslaught
      </a>
      , the teenaged Stark dies, along with many other superheroes.
      <a href="/wiki/Franklin_Richards" title="Franklin Richards">
       Franklin Richards
      </a>
      preserves these "dead" heroes in the "
      <a href="/wiki/Heroes_Reborn" title="Heroes Reborn">
       Heroes Reborn
      </a>
      " pocket universe, in which Anthony Stark is once again an adult hero; Franklin recreates the heroes in the pocket universe in the forms he is most familiar with rather than what they are at the present. The reborn adult Stark, upon returning to the normal Marvel Universe, merges with the original Stark, who had died during "The Crossing", but was resurrected by Franklin Richards. This new Anthony Stark possesses the memories of both the original and teenage Anthony Starks, and thus considers himself to be essentially both of them. With the aid of the law firm
      <a href="/wiki/Daredevil_(Marvel_Comics)" title="Daredevil (Marvel Comics)">
       Nelson &amp; Murdock
      </a>
      , he successfully regains his fortune and, with Stark Enterprises having been sold to the Fujikawa Corporation following Stark's death, sets up a new company, Stark Solutions. He returns from the pocket universe with a restored and healthy heart. After the Avengers reform, Stark demands a hearing be convened to look into his actions just prior to the Onslaught incident. Cleared of wrongdoing, he rejoins the Avengers.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">
         <span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific volume in which the source appears. (August 2014)">
          volume &amp; issue needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="2000s">
       2000s
      </span>
     </h3>
     <table class="metadata plainlinks ambox ambox-style ambox-Plot" role="presentation">
      <tr>
       <td class="mbox-image">
        <div style="width:52px;">
         <img alt="" data-file-height="48" data-file-width="48" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/40px-Edit-clear.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/60px-Edit-clear.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/80px-Edit-clear.svg.png 2x" width="40"/>
        </div>
       </td>
       <td class="mbox-text">
        <span class="mbox-text-span">
         This article's plot summary
         <b>
          may be
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:How_to_write_a_plot_summary#What_to_cut" title="Wikipedia:How to write a plot summary">
           too long
          </a>
          or
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:How_to_write_a_plot_summary" title="Wikipedia:How to write a plot summary">
           excessively detailed
          </a>
          .
         </b>
         <span class="hide-when-compact">
          Please
          <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iron_Man&amp;action=edit">
           help improve it
          </a>
          by removing unnecessary details and making it more concise.
         </span>
         <small>
          <i>
           (December 2013)
          </i>
         </small>
        </span>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      At one point, Stark's armor becomes sentient despite fail-safes to prevent its increasingly sophisticated computer systems from doing so. Initially, Stark welcomes this "living" armor for its improved tactical abilities. The armor begins to grow more aggressive, killing indiscriminately and eventually desiring to replace Stark altogether. In the final confrontation on a desert island, Stark suffers another heart attack. The armor sacrifices its own existence to save its creator's life, giving up essential components to give Stark a new, artificial heart. This new heart solves Stark's health problems, but it does not have an internal power supply, so Stark becomes once again dependent on periodic recharging. The sentient armor incident so disturbs Stark that he temporarily returns to using an unsophisticated early model version of his armor to avoid a repeat incident. He dabbles with using liquid metal circuitry known as S.K.I.N. that forms into a protective shell around his body, but eventually returns to more conventional hard metal armors.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">
         <span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific volume in which the source appears. (September 2013)">
          volume &amp; issue needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      During this time, Stark engages in a romance with
      <a href="/wiki/Rumiko_Fujikawa" title="Rumiko Fujikawa">
       Rumiko Fujikawa
      </a>
      (first appearance in
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      (vol. 3) #4), a wealthy heiress and daughter of the man who had taken over his company during the "Heroes Reborn" period. Her relationship with Stark endures many highs and lows, including an infidelity with Stark's rival, Tiberius Stone, in part because the fun-loving Rumiko believes that Stark is too serious and dull. Their relationship ends with Rumiko's death at the hands of an Iron Man impostor in
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      (vol. 3) #87.
     </p>
     <p>
      In
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      (vol. 3) #55 (July 2002), Stark publicly reveals his dual identity as Iron Man, not realizing that by doing so, he has invalidated the agreements protecting his armor from government duplication, since those contracts state that the Iron Man armor would be used by an
      <i>
       employee
      </i>
      of Tony Stark, not by Stark himself. When he discovers that the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_of_the_United_States" title="Military of the United States">
       United States military
      </a>
      is again using his technology, Stark accepts a
      <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">
       Presidential
      </a>
      appointment as
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Defense" title="United States Secretary of Defense">
       Secretary of Defense
      </a>
      instead of confronting them as he did before. In this way, he hopes to monitor and direct how his designs are used.
     </p>
     <p>
      In the "
      <a href="/wiki/Avengers_Disassembled" title="Avengers Disassembled">
       Avengers Disassembled
      </a>
      " storyline, Stark is forced to resign after launching into a tirade against the
      <a href="/wiki/Latveria" title="Latveria">
       Latverian
      </a>
      ambassador at the
      <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
       United Nations
      </a>
      , being manipulated by the mentally imbalanced
      <a href="/wiki/Scarlet_Witch" title="Scarlet Witch">
       Scarlet Witch
      </a>
      , who destroys the Avengers Mansion and kills several members. Stark publicly stands down as Iron Man, but actually continues using the costume. He joins the Avengers in stopping the breakout in progress from
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Raft_(comics)" title="The Raft (comics)">
       the Raft
      </a>
      and even saves Captain America from falling.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
       <a href="#cite_note-65">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        65
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Tony changes the Avengers base to
      <a href="/wiki/Stark_Tower" title="Stark Tower">
       Stark Tower
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
       <a href="#cite_note-66">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        66
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Ghost_(Marvel_Comics)" title="Ghost (Marvel Comics)">
       Ghost
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Living_Laser" title="Living Laser">
       Living Laser
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Spymaster_(comics)" title="Spymaster (comics)">
       Spymaster
      </a>
      reappear and shift Iron Man from standard superhero stories to dealing with
      <a href="/wiki/Politics" title="Politics">
       politics
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Industrialism" title="Industrialism">
       industrialism
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
       <a href="#cite_note-67">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        67
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Illuminati_(comics)" title="Illuminati (comics)">
        New Avengers: Illuminati
       </a>
      </i>
      #1 (June 2006) reveals that years before, Stark had started participating with a group of leaders including the
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Panther_(comics)" title="Black Panther (comics)">
       Black Panther
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Professor_X" title="Professor X">
       Professor X
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mister_Fantastic" title="Mister Fantastic">
       Mister Fantastic
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Bolt" title="Black Bolt">
       Black Bolt
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Doctor_Strange" title="Doctor Strange">
       Doctor Strange
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Namor" title="Namor">
       Namor
      </a>
      . The goal of the group (dubbed the
      <a href="/wiki/Illuminati_(comics)" title="Illuminati (comics)">
       Illuminati
      </a>
      by Marvel) was to strategize overarching menaces, in which the Black Panther rejects a membership offer. Stark's goal is to create a governing body for all superheroes in the world, but the beliefs of its members instead force them all to share vital information.
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id=".22Civil_War.22">
       "Civil War"
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      In the "
      <a href="/wiki/Civil_War_(comics)" title="Civil War (comics)">
       Civil War
      </a>
      " storyline, after the actions of inexperienced superheroes
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_New_Warriors" title="The New Warriors">
       The New Warriors
      </a>
      result in the destruction of several city blocks, including the elementary school, in Stamford, Connecticut, there is an outcry across America against super-humans. Learning of the Government's proposed plans, Tony Stark suggests a new plan to instigate a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Superhuman_Registration_Act" title="Superhuman Registration Act">
       Superhuman Registration Act
      </a>
      . The Act would force every super-powered individual in the U.S. to register their identity with the government and act as licensed agents. The Act would force inexperienced super-humans to receive training in how to use and control their abilities, something in which Tony strongly believes. Since his struggle with alcoholism, Stark has carried a tremendous burden of guilt after nearly killing an innocent bystander while piloting the armor drunk. Reed Richards of the
      <a href="/wiki/Fantastic_Four" title="Fantastic Four">
       Fantastic Four
      </a>
      and Dr. Henry "Hank" Pym both agree with Stark's proposal; unfortunately, not everyone does. After
      <a href="/wiki/Captain_America" title="Captain America">
       Captain America
      </a>
      is ordered to bring in anyone who refuses to register, he and other anti-registration superheroes go rogue, coming into conflict with the pro-registration heroes, led by Iron Man. The war ends when Captain America surrenders to prevent further collateral damage and civilian casualties, although he had defeated Stark by defusing his armor. Stark is appointed the new director of S.H.I.E.L.D.,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
       <a href="#cite_note-68">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        68
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and organizes a new government-sanctioned group of
      <a href="/wiki/The_Mighty_Avengers" title="The Mighty Avengers">
       Avengers
      </a>
      . Shortly afterwards, Captain America is assassinated while in custody.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
       <a href="#cite_note-69">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        69
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      This leaves Stark with a great amount of guilt and misgivings about the cost of his victory and he states that "it wasn't worth it". He serves as one of the pallbearers at the memorial service for Captain America, along with Ben Grimm, Ms. Marvel, Rick Jones, T'Challa and Sam Wilson.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
       <a href="#cite_note-70">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        70
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id=".22Secret_Invasion.22">
       "Secret Invasion"
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      To tie into the 2008
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_(2008_film)" title="Iron Man (2008 film)">
        Iron Man
       </a>
      </i>
      feature film, Marvel launched a new
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      ongoing series,
      <i>
       The Invincible Iron Man
      </i>
      , with writer
      <a href="/wiki/Matt_Fraction" title="Matt Fraction">
       Matt Fraction
      </a>
      and artist
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salvador_Larocca" title="Salvador Larocca">
       Salvador Larocca
      </a>
      . The series inaugural six-part storyline was "The Five Nightmares", which saw Stark targeted by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ezekiel_Stane" title="Ezekiel Stane">
       Ezekiel Stane
      </a>
      , the son of Stark's former nemesis, Obadiah Stane.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
       <a href="#cite_note-71">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        71
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the "
      <a href="/wiki/Secret_Invasion" title="Secret Invasion">
       Secret Invasion
      </a>
      " storyline, after Tony Stark survives an encounter with
      <a href="/wiki/Ultron" title="Ultron">
       Ultron
      </a>
      taking over his body, he is confronted in the hospital by
      <a href="/wiki/Spider-Woman_(Jessica_Drew)" title="Spider-Woman (Jessica Drew)">
       Spider-Woman
      </a>
      , holding the corpse of a
      <a href="/wiki/Skrull" title="Skrull">
       Skrull
      </a>
      posing as
      <a href="/wiki/Elektra_(comics)" title="Elektra (comics)">
       Elektra
      </a>
      . Becoming keenly aware of the upcoming invasion of the Skrulls, Tony gathers the Illuminati and reveals the corpse to them, declaring that they are at war. After
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Bolt" title="Black Bolt">
       Black Bolt
      </a>
      reveals himself as a Skrull and is killed by
      <a href="/wiki/Namor" title="Namor">
       Namor
      </a>
      , a squadron of Skrulls attack, forcing Tony to evacuate the other Illuminati members and destroy the area, killing all the Skrulls. Realizing that they are incapable of trusting each other, the members all separate to form individual plans for the oncoming invasion.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">
         <span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific volume in which the source appears. (September 2013)">
          volume &amp; issue needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Stark is discredited and publicly vilified after his inability to anticipate or prevent a
      <a href="/wiki/Secret_Invasion" title="Secret Invasion">
       secret infiltration and invasion
      </a>
      of Earth by the shape-shifting alien
      <a href="/wiki/Skrull" title="Skrull">
       Skrull
      </a>
      race, and by the Skrull disabling of his StarkTech technology, which had a virtual monopoly on worldwide defense.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
       <a href="#cite_note-72">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        72
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      After the invasion, the U.S. government removes him as head of
      <a href="/wiki/S.H.I.E.L.D." title="S.H.I.E.L.D.">
       S.H.I.E.L.D.
      </a>
      and disbands the
      <a href="/wiki/Avengers_(comics)" title="Avengers (comics)">
       Avengers
      </a>
      , handing control of the
      <a href="/wiki/Fifty_State_Initiative" title="Fifty State Initiative">
       Initiative
      </a>
      over to
      <a href="/wiki/Green_Goblin" title="Green Goblin">
       Norman Osborn
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id=".22Dark_Reign.22">
       "Dark Reign"
      </span>
     </h4>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Dark_Reign_(comics)" title="Dark Reign (comics)">
       Dark Reign (comics)
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote boilerplate seealso">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/The_Invincible_Iron_Man" title="The Invincible Iron Man">
       The Invincible Iron Man
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      With his Extremis powers failing, Stark uploads a virus to destroy all records of the Registration Act, thus preventing Osborn from learning the identities of his fellow heroes and anything that Osborn could possibly exploit, including repulsor generators. The only copy of that database remaining is in Stark's brain, which he is trying to delete bit by bit while on the run in one of his extra armors.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
       <a href="#cite_note-73">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        73
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      As Norman Osborn has him hunted as a fugitive, Stark travels worldwide on his quest to wipe out his mental database, going so far as to inflict
      <a href="/wiki/Brain_damage" title="Brain damage">
       brain damage
      </a>
      on himself in order to ensure that the relevant information is wiped as a suicide attempt could damage the wrong parts of his brain while leaving Osborn with enough material to salvage the right information. When Osborn personally catches up to the debilitated Stark and beats him savagely,
      <a href="/wiki/Pepper_Potts" title="Pepper Potts">
       Pepper Potts
      </a>
      broadcasts the beatings worldwide, costing Osborn credibility and giving Stark public sympathy. Stark goes into a vegetative state, having previously granted
      <a href="/wiki/Thor_(Marvel_Comics)" title="Thor (Marvel Comics)">
       Donald Blake
      </a>
      (alter ego of the Norse-god superhero Thor) power of attorney.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
       <a href="#cite_note-74">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        74
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A holographic message stored in Pepper's armor reveals that Stark had developed a means of 'rebooting' his mind from his current state prior to his destruction of the database, with Blake and Bucky resolving to use it to restore him to normal despite Stark's offer in the message to stay in his current state if it would make things easier and Pepper's own uncertainty about the fact that Tony can come back when so many others cannot. Meanwhile, in Stark's subconscious, he is trapped in a scenario where figments of his own mind are preventing him from moving on and returning to the waking world. When the procedure fails to work, Bucky calls in Doctor Strange, who attempts to and succeeds in restoring Stark back to consciousness. It turns out the backup Stark created was made prior to the Civil War, and as such he does not remember anything that took place during the event, although he still concludes after reviewing his past actions that he would not have done anything differently. His brain damage means that he is now dependent on an arc reactor to sustain his body's autonomous functions such as breathing, blinking and a heartbeat due to the brain damage he sustained rendering it impossible for him to do those himself.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
       <a href="#cite_note-75">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        75
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="2010s">
       2010s
      </span>
     </h3>
     <table class="metadata plainlinks ambox ambox-style ambox-Plot" role="presentation">
      <tr>
       <td class="mbox-image">
        <div style="width:52px;">
         <img alt="" data-file-height="48" data-file-width="48" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/40px-Edit-clear.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/60px-Edit-clear.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/80px-Edit-clear.svg.png 2x" width="40"/>
        </div>
       </td>
       <td class="mbox-text">
        <span class="mbox-text-span">
         This article's plot summary
         <b>
          may be
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:How_to_write_a_plot_summary#What_to_cut" title="Wikipedia:How to write a plot summary">
           too long
          </a>
          or
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:How_to_write_a_plot_summary" title="Wikipedia:How to write a plot summary">
           excessively detailed
          </a>
          .
         </b>
         <span class="hide-when-compact">
          Please
          <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iron_Man&amp;action=edit">
           help improve it
          </a>
          by removing unnecessary details and making it more concise.
         </span>
         <small>
          <i>
           (December 2013)
          </i>
         </small>
        </span>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id=".22Siege.22">
       "Siege"
      </span>
     </h4>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Siege_(comics)" title="Siege (comics)">
       Siege (comics)
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      In the "
      <a href="/wiki/Siege_(comics)" title="Siege (comics)">
       Siege
      </a>
      " storyline, Tony Stark is seen under the care of
      <a href="/wiki/Thor_(Marvel_Comics)" title="Thor (Marvel Comics)">
       Dr. Donald Blake
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Maria_Hill" title="Maria Hill">
       Maria Hill
      </a>
      . When the two spot the attack on Asgard, Blake tells Maria to run away with Stark.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
       <a href="#cite_note-76">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        76
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Hill leaves Stark to assist Blake, now as
      <a href="/wiki/Thor_(Marvel_Comics)" title="Thor (Marvel Comics)">
       Thor
      </a>
      , after his ambush by
      <a href="/wiki/Green_Goblin" title="Green Goblin">
       Osborn
      </a>
      and his attack dog the
      <a href="/wiki/Sentry_(Robert_Reynolds)" title="Sentry (Robert Reynolds)">
       Sentry
      </a>
      . Hill rescues Thor and brings him back to Broxton to recuperate. When Osborn declares
      <a href="/wiki/Martial_law" title="Martial law">
       martial law
      </a>
      and unleashes
      <a href="/wiki/Daken" title="Daken">
       Daken
      </a>
      and the Sentry on Broxton to root out Thor and Hill, Thor reveals himself to defend the town. Hill returns to Tony Stark's hiding place to move him to a safer location and are joined soon after by
      <a href="/wiki/Speed_(comics)" title="Speed (comics)">
       Speed
      </a>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/Young_Avengers" title="Young Avengers">
       Young Avengers
      </a>
      , who holds a certain
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man%27s_armor" title="Iron Man's armor">
       indestructible suitcase
      </a>
      that Edwin Jarvis had given Captain America earlier. Hill orders Speed to surrender when Stark stops her and asks Speed to give him the case. While Osborn is battling the
      <a href="/wiki/The_New_Avengers_(comics)" title="The New Avengers (comics)">
       New Avengers
      </a>
      , Stark appears in a variant of his MK III armor and proceeds to disable Osborn's Iron Patriot armor. Osborn orders the Sentry to annihilate Asgard, rather than allow the Avengers to have it, which the Sentry does, practically leveling the city before the horrified eyes of Thor. After Asgard falls, literally, Stark stands alongside his fellow heroes, as the now armor-free Osborn exclaims they are all doomed and he 'was saving them from him' pointing up towards a
      <a href="/wiki/Sentry_(Robert_Reynolds)#Void" title="Sentry (Robert Reynolds)">
       Void
      </a>
      -possessed Sentry hovering over them.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
       <a href="#cite_note-77">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        77
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      As the Void tears apart the teams, Loki gives them the power to fight back through the
      <a href="/wiki/Norn_Stones" title="Norn Stones">
       Norn Stones
      </a>
      . When the Void kills Loki, Thor's rage-fueled blows rattle the creature. Tony then tells Thor to get the Void away from Asgard, which he does. Tony then drops the commandeered H.A.M.M.E.R. Helicarrier 'as a bullet', subduing the Void. When Robert Reynolds begs to be killed, Thor denies the request, but is forced to when the Void resurfaces. Sometime later, the Super-Human Registration Act is repealed and Tony is given back his company and armory. As a symbol for their heroics and their new unity, Thor places a remaining Asgardian tower on Stark Tower where the Watchtower once stood.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
       <a href="#cite_note-78">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        78
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id=".22Heroic_Age.22">
       "Heroic Age"
      </span>
     </h4>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Heroic_Age_(comics)" title="Heroic Age (comics)">
       Heroic Age (comics)
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      In the 2010-2011 "Stark: Resilient" storyline, Tony builds a new armor, the Bleeding Edge, with the help of Mister Fantastic. This new armor fully utilizes the repulsor tech battery embedded in his chest to power Tony's entire body and mind thus allowing him access to extremis once more. Furthermore, the battery operates as his "heart" and is predominantly the only thing keeping him alive.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fraction.2C_Matt_2010_79-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Fraction.2C_Matt_2010-79">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        79
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Later, Tony announces that he will form a new company, Stark Resilient. He states that he will stop developing weapons, instead, he plans to use his repulsor technology to give free energy to the world. Justine and Sasha Hammer create their own armored hero, Detroit Steel, to take Stark's place as the Army's leading weapons-builder. Stark's plan consists of building two repulsor-powered cars. The Hammers try to foil his efforts. The first car is destroyed by sabotage, while Detroit Steel attacks Stark Resilient's facilities while Tony tests the second car. Through a legal maneuver, Tony is able to get the Hammers to stop their attacks and releases a successful commercial about his new car.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
       <a href="#cite_note-80">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        80
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
       <a href="#cite_note-81">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        81
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id=".22Fear_Itself.22">
       "Fear Itself"
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      In the 2011 "
      <a href="/wiki/Fear_Itself_(comics)" title="Fear Itself (comics)">
       Fear Itself
      </a>
      " storyline, Earth is attacked by the Serpent, brother of Odin.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
       <a href="#cite_note-82">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        82
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In Paris, Iron Man fights
      <a href="/wiki/Grey_Gargoyle" title="Grey Gargoyle">
       Grey Gargoyle
      </a>
      , who has become Mokk, Breaker of Faith and one of the Serpent's Worthy. Mokk leaves Iron Man unconscious and transforms Detroit Steel into stone. When Iron Man awakens, he sees that Mokk has turned all the people in Paris into stone and left.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
       <a href="#cite_note-83">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        83
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
       <a href="#cite_note-84">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        84
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      To defeat the Serpent's army, Tony drinks a bottle of wine - thus 'sacrificing' his sobriety - to gain an audience with Odin, who allows Tony to enter the realm of Svartalfheim. There, Tony and the dwarves of Svartalfheim work to build weapons the Avengers can use against the Worthy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
       <a href="#cite_note-85">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        85
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Tony upgrades his armor with uru-infused enchantments and delivers the finished weapons to the Avengers, who use them for the final battle against the Serpent's forces. Iron Man watches as Thor kills the Serpent, but dies in the process. After the battle is over, Tony melts down the weapons he created and repairs Captain America's shield, which had been broken by Serpent, and gives it back to Captain America, telling him that the shield is now stronger.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
       <a href="#cite_note-86">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        86
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      During a subsequent argument with Odin about the gods' lack of involvement in the recent crisis, Odin gives Tony a brief opportunity to see the vastness of the universe the way he sees it, before, as thanks for Tony's role in the recent crisis, he restores all the people that the Grey Gargoyle killed during his rampage.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
       <a href="#cite_note-87">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        87
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Return_of_the_Mandarin_and_Marvel_NOW.21">
       Return of the Mandarin and Marvel NOW!
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      In the storylines "Demon" and "The Long Way Down", Stark is subpoenaed by the U.S. government after evidence surfaces of him using the Iron Man armor while under the influence of intoxicants. Mandarin and Zeke Stane upgrade some of Iron Man's old enemies and send them to commit acts of terrorism across the world, intending to discredit Iron Man. General Bruce Babbage forces Stark to wear a tech governor, a device that allows Babbage to deactivate Stark's armor whenever he wants. To fight back, Tony undergoes a surgical procedure that expels the Bleeding Edge technology out of his body and replaces his repulsor node with a new model, forcing Babbage to remove the tech governor off his chest. He announces his retirement as Iron Man, faking Rhodes' death and giving him a new armor so that he becomes the new Iron Man.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
       <a href="#cite_note-88">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        88
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      This leads into the next storyline, "The Future", in which the Mandarin takes control of Stark's mind and uses him to create new armored bodies for the alien spirits inhabiting his rings, but Stark allies himself with some of his old enemies, who have also been imprisoned by Mandarin, and manages to defeat and escape him. The final issue of this storyline concluded Matt Fraction's series.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IronMan523_89-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-IronMan523-89">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        89
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the ongoing series that premiered in 2012 as part of the
      <a href="/wiki/Marvel_NOW!" title="Marvel NOW!">
       Marvel NOW!
      </a>
      relaunch, Tony Stark has hit a technological ceiling. After the death of Dr. Maya Hansen and the destruction of all of the Extremis Ver. 2 kits that were being sold to the black market, Tony decides that the Earth is not safe without him learning more from what's in the final frontier. He takes his new suit, enhanced with an artificial intelligence named P.E.P.P.E.R. and joins
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peter_Quill" title="Peter Quill">
       Peter Quill
      </a>
      and The
      <a href="/wiki/Guardians_of_the_Galaxy_(2008_team)" title="Guardians of the Galaxy (2008 team)">
       Guardians of the Galaxy
      </a>
      after helping them thwart a Badoon attack on Earth.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
       <a href="#cite_note-90">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        90
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Powers_and_abilities">
       Powers and abilities
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Armor">
       Armor
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote boilerplate seealso">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man%27s_armor" title="Iron Man's armor">
       Iron Man's armor
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:IronManV5No25.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="213" data-file-width="495" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/63/IronManV5No25.jpg/350px-IronManV5No25.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/6/63/IronManV5No25.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/6/63/IronManV5No25.jpg 2x" width="350"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:IronManV5No25.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The Bleeding Edge Armor, like the Extremis Armor before it, is stored in Stark's bones, and can be assembled and controlled by his thoughts.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Iron Man possesses
      <a href="/wiki/Powered_exoskeleton" title="Powered exoskeleton">
       powered armor
      </a>
      that gives him superhuman strength and durability, flight, and an array of weapons. The armor is invented and worn by Stark (with occasional short-term exceptions). Other people who have assumed the Iron Man identity include Stark's long-time partner and best friend
      <a href="/wiki/War_Machine" title="War Machine">
       James Rhodes
      </a>
      ;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DeFalco211_37-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-DeFalco211-37">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        37
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      close associates
      <a href="/wiki/Happy_Hogan" title="Happy Hogan">
       Harold "Happy" Hogan
      </a>
      ; Eddie March;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
       <a href="#cite_note-91">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        91
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
       <a href="#cite_note-92">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        92
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and (briefly)
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guardsman_(Michael_O%27Brien)" title="Guardsman (Michael O'Brien)">
       Michael O'Brien
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      The weapons systems of the suit have changed over the years, but Iron Man's standard offensive weapons have always been the repulsor rays that are fired from the palms of his
      <a href="/wiki/Gauntlet_(glove)" title="Gauntlet (glove)">
       gauntlets
      </a>
      . Other weapons built into various incarnations of the armor include: the uni-beam projector in its chest; pulse bolts (that pick up
      <a href="/wiki/Kinetic_energy" title="Kinetic energy">
       kinetic energy
      </a>
      along the way; so the farther they travel, the harder they hit); an
      <a href="/wiki/Electromagnetic_pulse" title="Electromagnetic pulse">
       electromagnetic pulse
      </a>
      generator; and a defensive energy shield that can be extended up to 360 degrees. Other capabilities include: generating ultra-
      <a href="/wiki/Freon" title="Freon">
       freon
      </a>
      (i.e., a freeze-beam); creating and manipulating
      <a href="/wiki/Magnetic_field" title="Magnetic field">
       magnetic fields
      </a>
      ; emitting sonic blasts; and projecting 3-dimensional
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hologram" title="Hologram">
       holograms
      </a>
      (to create decoys).
     </p>
     <p>
      In addition to the general-purpose model he wears, Stark has developed several specialized
      <a href="/wiki/Space_suit" title="Space suit">
       suits
      </a>
      for
      <a href="/wiki/Spaceflight" title="Spaceflight">
       space travel
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IronMan142_31-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-IronMan142-31">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        31
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Atmospheric_diving_suit" title="Atmospheric diving suit">
       deep-sea diving
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Stealth_technology" title="Stealth technology">
       stealth
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DeFalco202_32-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-DeFalco202-32">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        32
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IronMan152_33-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-IronMan152-33">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        33
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and other special purposes. Stark has modified suits, like the Hulkbuster heavy armor. The Hulkbuster armor is composed of add-ons to his so-called modular armor, designed to enhance its strength and durability enough to engage the Incredible
      <a href="/wiki/Hulk_(comics)" title="Hulk (comics)">
       Hulk
      </a>
      in a fight. A later model, designed for use against
      <a href="/wiki/Thor_(Marvel_Comics)" title="Thor (Marvel Comics)">
       Thor
      </a>
      , is modeled on the
      <a href="/wiki/Destroyer_(Thor)" title="Destroyer (Thor)">
       Destroyer
      </a>
      and uses a mystical power source. Stark develops an electronics pack during the Armor Wars that, when attached to armors that use Stark technologies, will burn out those components, rendering the suit useless. This pack is ineffective on later models. While it is typically associated with
      <a href="/wiki/War_Machine" title="War Machine">
       James Rhodes
      </a>
      , the War Machine armor began as one of Stark's specialty armors.
     </p>
     <p>
      The most recent models of Stark's armor, beginning with the Extremis Armor, are now stored in the hollow portions of Stark's bones, and the personal area networking implement used to control it is implanted in his forearm, and connected directly to his
      <a href="/wiki/Central_nervous_system" title="Central nervous system">
       central nervous system
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      The Extremis has since been removed,
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">
         <span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific volume in which the source appears. (April 2014)">
          volume &amp; issue needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      and he now uses more conventional armors. Some armors still take a liquid form but are not stored within his body.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Powers">
       Powers
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      After being critically injured during a battle with the Extremis-enhanced Mallen, Stark injects his nervous system with modified techno-organic virus-like body restructuring machines (the Extremis process).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
       <a href="#cite_note-93">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        93
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      By rewriting his own biology, Stark is able to save his life, gain an enhanced
      <a href="/wiki/Healing_factor" title="Healing factor">
       healing factor
      </a>
      , and partially merge with the Iron Man armor, superseding the need for bulky, AI-controlled armors in favor of lighter designs, technopathically controlled by his own brain. His enhanced technopathy extends to every piece of technology, limitless and effortlessly due to his ability to interface with communication satellites and wireless connections to increase his "range". Some components of the armor-sheath are now stored in Tony's body, able to be recalled, and extruded from his own skin, at will.
     </p>
     <p>
      During the "
      <a href="/wiki/Secret_Invasion" title="Secret Invasion">
       Secret Invasion
      </a>
      " storyline the Extremis package is catastrophically shutdown by a virus, forcing him again to rely on the previous iteration of his armor, and restoring his previous limitations. Furthermore, Osborn's takeover of most of the few remaining Starktech factories, with Ezekiel Stane systematically crippling the others, limits Tony to the use of lesser, older and weaker armors.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
       <a href="#cite_note-94">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        94
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      After being forced to "wipe out" his brain to prevent Norman Osborn from gaining his information, Tony Stark is forced to have a new arc reactor, of
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Fist_(comics)" title="Iron Fist (comics)">
       Rand
      </a>
      design installed in his chest. The process greatly improves his strength, stamina and intellect. The procedure left him with virtually no autonomic functions: as his brain was stripped of every biological function, Tony is forced to rely on a digital backup of his memories (leaving him with severe gaps and lapses in his long-term memory) and on software routine in the arc reactor for basic stimuli reaction, such as blinking and breathing.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
       <a href="#cite_note-95">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        95
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
       <a href="#cite_note-96">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        96
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <i>
       Bleeding Edge
      </i>
      package of armor and physical enhancement is now equal in power, if not a more advanced, version of the old Extremis tech.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fraction.2C_Matt_2010_79-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Fraction.2C_Matt_2010-79">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        79
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Skills">
       Skills
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Tony Stark is an inventive genius whose expertise in the fields of
      <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">
       mathematics
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Physics" title="Physics">
       physics
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Chemistry" title="Chemistry">
       chemistry
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Computer_science" title="Computer science">
       computer science
      </a>
      rivals that of
      <a href="/wiki/Mister_Fantastic" title="Mister Fantastic">
       Reed Richards
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Hank_Pym" title="Hank Pym">
       Hank Pym
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Hulk_(comics)" title="Hulk (comics)">
       Bruce Banner
      </a>
      , and his expertise in
      <a href="/wiki/Electrical_engineering" title="Electrical engineering">
       electrical engineering
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Mechanical_engineering" title="Mechanical engineering">
       mechanical engineering
      </a>
      surpasses even theirs. He is regarded as one of the most intelligent characters in the Marvel Universe. He graduated with advanced degrees in physics and engineering at the age of 17 from
      <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology" title="Massachusetts Institute of Technology">
       Massachusetts Institute of Technology
      </a>
      (MIT)
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
       <a href="#cite_note-97">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        97
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and further developed his knowledge ranging from
      <a href="/wiki/Artificial_intelligence" title="Artificial intelligence">
       artificial intelligence
      </a>
      to
      <a href="/wiki/Quantum_mechanics" title="Quantum mechanics">
       quantum mechanics
      </a>
      as time progressed. His expertise extends to his ingenuity in dealing with difficult situations, such as difficult foes and deathtraps, in which he is capable of using available tools, including his suit, in unorthodox but effective ways. He is well respected in the business world, able to command people's attention when he speaks on economic matters, having over the years built up several multi-million dollar companies from virtually nothing. He is noted for the loyalty he commands from and returns to those who work for him, as well as for his business ethics. Thus he immediately fired an employee who made profitable, but illegal, sales to
      <a href="/wiki/Doctor_Doom" title="Doctor Doom">
       Doctor Doom
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IronMan149_34-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-IronMan149-34">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        34
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He strives to be environmentally responsible in his businesses.
     </p>
     <p>
      At a time when Stark was unable to use his armor for a period, he received some combat training from
      <a href="/wiki/Captain_America" title="Captain America">
       Captain America
      </a>
      and has become physically formidable on his own when the situation demands it.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
       <a href="#cite_note-98">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        98
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In addition, Stark possesses great business and political acumen. On multiple occasions he reacquired control of his companies after losing them amid corporate takeovers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
       <a href="#cite_note-99">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        99
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Due to his membership in the Illuminati, Iron Man was given the Space
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Infinity_Gem" title="Infinity Gem">
       Infinity Gem
      </a>
      to safeguard.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
       <a href="#cite_note-100">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        100
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It allows the user to exist in any location (or all locations), move any object anywhere throughout the universe and warp or rearrange space. As with the other members of the lluminati and their respective gems, Iron Man has vowed not to use it on any occasion, even after the Secret Invasion and his fugitive status.
     </p>
     <p>
      It was suggested that Stark's intelligence was the result of experiments made by a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Recorder_(comics)" title="Recorder (comics)">
       Rigellian recorder
      </a>
      called
      <a href="/wiki/Recorder_451" title="Recorder 451">
       Recorder 451
      </a>
      after his mother almost loses him while pregnant, in exchange of saving his life.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
       <a href="#cite_note-101">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        101
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, it was revealed that Tony was really adopted and the true son of Howard and Maria Stark is
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arno_Stark" title="Arno Stark">
       Arno
      </a>
      , weakened by 451's experiments.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
       <a href="#cite_note-102">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        102
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Other_versions">
       Other versions
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Alternative_versions_of_Iron_Man" title="Alternative versions of Iron Man">
       Alternative versions of Iron Man
      </a>
     </div>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="In_other_media">
       In other media
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_in_other_media" title="Iron Man in other media">
       Iron Man in other media
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      In 1966, Iron Man was featured in a series of cartoons.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
       <a href="#cite_note-103">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        103
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1981, Iron Man guest appeared in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Spider-Man_and_His_Amazing_Friends" title="Spider-Man and His Amazing Friends">
        Spider-Man and His Amazing Friends
       </a>
      </i>
      , but only as Tony Stark.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
       <a href="#cite_note-104">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        104
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He went on to feature again in his own series in the 1990s as part of the
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marvel_Action_Hour" title="Marvel Action Hour">
        Marvel Action Hour
       </a>
      </i>
      with the Fantastic Four;
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_Hays" title="Robert Hays">
       Robert Hays
      </a>
      provided his voice in these animated cartoons. Iron Man makes an appearance in the episode "Shell Games" of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Fantastic_Four:_World%27s_Greatest_Heroes" title="Fantastic Four: World's Greatest Heroes">
        Fantastic Four: World's Greatest Heroes
       </a>
       .
      </i>
      Apart from comic books, Iron Man appears in Capcom's
      <i>
       "Vs."
      </i>
      video games, including
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marvel_Super_Heroes_(arcade_game)" title="Marvel Super Heroes (arcade game)">
        Marvel Super Heroes
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Marvel_vs._Capcom:_Clash_of_Super_Heroes" title="Marvel vs. Capcom: Clash of Super Heroes">
        Marvel vs. Capcom: Clash of Super Heroes
       </a>
      </i>
      as either a Gold War Machine or Hyper Armor War Machine,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Marvel_vs._Capcom_2:_New_Age_of_Heroes" title="Marvel vs. Capcom 2: New Age of Heroes">
        Marvel vs. Capcom 2: New Age of Heroes
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Marvel_vs._Capcom_3:_Fate_of_Two_Worlds" title="Marvel vs. Capcom 3: Fate of Two Worlds">
        Marvel vs. Capcom 3: Fate of Two Worlds
       </a>
      </i>
      , and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Ultimate_Marvel_vs._Capcom_3" title="Ultimate Marvel vs. Capcom 3">
        Ultimate Marvel vs. Capcom 3
       </a>
      </i>
      . Iron Man is a playable character in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_(video_game)" title="Iron Man (video game)">
        Iron Man
       </a>
      </i>
      , the 1992 arcade game
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Captain_America_and_the_Avengers" title="Captain America and the Avengers">
        Captain America and the Avengers
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Marvel:_Ultimate_Alliance" title="Marvel: Ultimate Alliance">
        Marvel: Ultimate Alliance
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Marvel:_Ultimate_Alliance_2" title="Marvel: Ultimate Alliance 2">
       its sequel
      </a>
      , and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Marvel_Nemesis:_Rise_of_the_Imperfects" title="Marvel Nemesis: Rise of the Imperfects">
        Marvel Nemesis: Rise of the Imperfects
       </a>
      </i>
      , as well as being featured as an unlockable character in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/X-Men_Legends_II:_Rise_of_Apocalypse" title="X-Men Legends II: Rise of Apocalypse">
        X-Men Legends II: Rise of Apocalypse
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Tony_Hawk%27s_Underground" title="Tony Hawk's Underground">
        Tony Hawk's Underground
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
       <a href="#cite_note-105">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        105
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the 2009 animated series,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man:_Armored_Adventures" title="Iron Man: Armored Adventures">
        Iron Man: Armored Adventures
       </a>
      </i>
      , most of the characters, including Tony Stark, are teenagers. An
      <a href="/wiki/Marvel_Anime" title="Marvel Anime">
       anime adaptation
      </a>
      began airing in Japan in October 2010 as part of a collaboration between
