      <a href="/wiki/Marvel_Animation" title="Marvel Animation">
       Marvel Animation
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Madhouse_(company)" title="Madhouse (company)">
       Madhouse
      </a>
      , in which Stark, voiced by
      <a href="/wiki/Keiji_Fujiwara" title="Keiji Fujiwara">
       Keiji Fujiwara
      </a>
      , travels to Japan where he ends up facing off against the Zodiac.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
       <a href="#cite_note-106">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        106
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2008, a film adaptation titled
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_(2008_film)" title="Iron Man (2008 film)">
        Iron Man
       </a>
      </i>
      was released, starring
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_Downey,_Jr." title="Robert Downey, Jr.">
       Robert Downey, Jr.
      </a>
      as Tony Stark and directed by
      <a href="/wiki/Jon_Favreau" title="Jon Favreau">
       Jon Favreau
      </a>
      .
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      received very positive reviews from film critics,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
       <a href="#cite_note-107">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        107
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      grossing $318 million domestically and $585 million worldwide.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-boxmojo_108-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-boxmojo-108">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        108
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Its video game adaptation met generally negative reviews.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
       <a href="#cite_note-109">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        109
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The character of Tony Stark, again played by Robert Downey, Jr., appeared at the end of the 2008 film
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Incredible_Hulk_(film)" title="The Incredible Hulk (film)">
        The Incredible Hulk
       </a>
      </i>
      . Downey reprised his role in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_2" title="Iron Man 2">
        Iron Man 2
       </a>
      </i>
      (2010),
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Avengers_(2012_film)" title="The Avengers (2012 film)">
        Marvel's The Avengers
       </a>
      </i>
      (2012), and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_3" title="Iron Man 3">
        Iron Man 3
       </a>
      </i>
      (2013), and will appear in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Avengers:_Age_of_Ultron" title="Avengers: Age of Ultron">
        Avengers: Age of Ultron
       </a>
      </i>
      (2015), and a third
      <i>
       Avengers
      </i>
      film (TBA).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
       <a href="#cite_note-110">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        110
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural_influence">
       Cultural influence
      </span>
     </h2>
     <ul>
      <li>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Rapping" title="Rapping">
        rapper
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Ghostface_Killah" title="Ghostface Killah">
        Ghostface Killah
       </a>
       , a member of
       <a href="/wiki/Wu-Tang_Clan" title="Wu-Tang Clan">
        Wu-Tang Clan
       </a>
       , titled his 1996 debut solo album
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Ironman_(Ghostface_Killah_album)" title="Ironman (Ghostface Killah album)">
         Ironman
        </a>
       </i>
       , and has since continued to use lyrics related to the Iron Man comics and
       <a href="/wiki/Sampling_(music)" title="Sampling (music)">
        samples
       </a>
       from the animated TV shows on his records.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
        <a href="#cite_note-111">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         111
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shaheem_112-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Shaheem-112">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         112
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       He has adopted the nickname Tony Starks as one of his numerous alter-egos
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shaheem_112-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Shaheem-112">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         112
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       and was featured in a scene deleted from the
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_(2008_film)" title="Iron Man (2008 film)">
        <i>
         Iron Man
        </i>
        film
       </a>
       .
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Paul_McCartney" title="Paul McCartney">
        Paul McCartney
       </a>
       's song "
       <a href="/wiki/Magneto_and_Titanium_Man" title="Magneto and Titanium Man">
        Magneto and Titanium Man
       </a>
       " was inspired by the
       <a href="/wiki/X-Men" title="X-Men">
        X-Men
       </a>
       's nemesis and the original version of the Iron Man villain. Another Iron Man villain, the Crimson Dynamo, is mentioned in the lyrics to this song.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
        <a href="#cite_note-113">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         113
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
        <a href="#cite_note-114">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         114
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
      <li>
       The British band
       <a href="/wiki/Razorlight" title="Razorlight">
        Razorlight
       </a>
       mentions Tony Stark in a verse of their song, "Hang By, Hang By".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
        <a href="#cite_note-115">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         115
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
      <li>
       The character of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nathan_Stark" title="Nathan Stark">
        Nathan Stark
       </a>
       on the television show
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Eureka_(U.S._TV_series)" title="Eureka (U.S. TV series)">
         Eureka
        </a>
       </i>
       is inspired by Tony Stark.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
        <a href="#cite_note-116">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         116
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
      <li>
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">
         Forbes
        </a>
       </i>
       has ranked Iron Man among the wealthiest fictional characters on their annual ranking,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
        <a href="#cite_note-117">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         117
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       while
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BusinessWeek" title="BusinessWeek">
         BusinessWeek
        </a>
       </i>
       has ranked him as one of the ten most intelligent characters in American comics.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
        <a href="#cite_note-118">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         118
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
      <li>
       In 2011,
       <a href="/wiki/IGN" title="IGN">
        IGN
       </a>
       ranked Iron Man 12th in the Top 100 Comic Book Heroes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
        <a href="#cite_note-119">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         119
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
      <li>
       Two Iron Man-themed trucks compete in the
       <a href="/wiki/Monster_Jam" title="Monster Jam">
        Monster Jam
       </a>
       monster truck racing series. Debuted in Atlanta on 9 January 2010, they are driven by Lee O' Donnell and Morgan Kane.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
        <a href="#cite_note-120">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         120
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
     </ul>

          </a>
          ; Gilbert, Laura, ed. (2008). "1960s".
          <i>

          </i>

          <a href="/wiki/Dorling_Kindersley" title="Dorling Kindersley">

           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0756641238" title="Special:BookSources/978-0756641238">
           978-0756641238
          </a>
          . "Set against the background of the Vietnam War, Iron Man signaled the end of Marvel's monster/suspense line when he debuted in
          <i>
           Tales of Suspense
          </i>
          #39...[Stan] Lee discussed the general outline for Iron Man with Larry Lieber, who later wrote a full script for the origin story. Don Heck...designed the new character.""

          .
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIron+Man&amp;rft.au=Beard%2C+Jim&amp;rft.aufirst=Jim&amp;rft.aulast=Beard&amp;rft.btitle=Spotlight+on+Iron+Man%2FTony+Stark&amp;rft.date=July+12%2C+2007&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fmarvel.com%2Fnews%2Fstory%2F424%2Fspotlight_on_iron_mantony_stark&amp;rft.pub=Marvel+Comics&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-18">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-18">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         DeFalco "1960s" in Gilbert (2008), p. 128: "Hailing 1968 as the beginning of the 'Second Age of Marvel Comics,' and with more titles to play with, editor Stan Lee discarded his split books and gave more characters their own titles."
        </span>
       </li>

          <i>
           The Art of George Tuska
          </i>
          .
          <a href="/wiki/TwoMorrows_Publishing" title="TwoMorrows Publishing">

          <a class="external text" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20090304145337/http://forum.newsarama.com/showthread.php?t=128887" rel="nofollow">

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIron+Man&amp;rft.aufirst=Benjamin&amp;rft.aulast=Ong+Pang+Kean&amp;rft.au=Ong+Pang+Kean%2C+Benjamin&amp;rft.btitle=Forging+Iron%3A+Adi+Granov+talks+Iron+Man&amp;rft.date=September+11%2C+2007&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fforum.newsarama.com%2Fshowthread.php%3Ft%3D128887&amp;rft.pub=Newsarama&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

       <li id="cite_note-vol4-48">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         ^
         <a href="#cite_ref-vol4_48-0">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             a
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
         <a href="#cite_ref-vol4_48-1">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>

         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation web">
          Ching, Albert (October 14, 2012).
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.newsarama.com/10360-brian-bendis-adds-iron-man-to-guardians-of-the-galaxy.html" rel="nofollow">

           <i>
            Guardians of the Galaxy
           </i>
           "
          </a>
          . Newsarama.
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.webcitation.org/6GhLBTyEE" rel="nofollow">
           Archived
          </a>
          from the original on May 17, 2013
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved May 17, 2013
          </span>
          . "The Guardians are going to have a very specific agenda that’s much more Earth-based, even though there’s still going to be them in a spaceship guarding the galaxy, but they’re guarding the galaxy for Earth. And that’s what brings Iron Man to the team."
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIron+Man&amp;rft.au=Ching%2C+Albert&amp;rft.aufirst=Albert&amp;rft.aulast=Ching&amp;rft.btitle=Brian+Bendis+Adds+Iron+Man+to+Guardians+of+the+Galaxy&amp;rft.date=October+14%2C+2012&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.newsarama.com%2F10360-brian-bendis-adds-iron-man-to-guardians-of-the-galaxy.html&amp;rft.pub=Newsarama&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">

       <li id="cite_note-103">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-103">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation book">
          <a href="/wiki/Roy_Thomas" title="Roy Thomas">
           Thomas, Roy
          </a>
          ;
          <a href="/wiki/Peter_Sanderson" title="Peter Sanderson">
           Sanderson, Peter
          </a>
          (2007).
          <i>
           The Marvel Vault: A Museum-in-a-Book with Rare Collectibles from the World of Marvel
          </i>
          .
          <a href="/wiki/Running_Press" title="Running Press">
           Running Press
          </a>
          . p. 101.
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0762428441" title="Special:BookSources/978-0762428441">
           978-0762428441
          </a>
          . "In 1966, television production company Grantray-Lawrence produced a series of five half-hour semi-animated shows under the banner title
          <i>
           Marvel Superheroes
          </i>
          .
          <i>
           Captain America
          </i>
          ,
          <i>
           The Incredible Hulk
          </i>
          ,
          <i>
           Iron Man
          </i>
          ,
          <i>
           The Mighty Thor
          </i>
          , and
          <i>
           Sub-Mariner
          </i>
          all made their television debuts."
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIron+Man&amp;rft.aufirst=Roy&amp;rft.aulast=Thomas&amp;rft.au=Sanderson%2C+Peter&amp;rft.au=Thomas%2C+Roy&amp;rft.btitle=The+Marvel+Vault%3A+A+Museum-in-a-Book+with+Rare+Collectibles+from+the+World+of+Marvel&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-0762428441&amp;rft.pages=101&amp;rft.pub=Running+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>

        </span>

         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIron+Man&amp;rft.aufirst=Melissa&amp;rft.au=Hank%2C+Melissa&amp;rft.aulast=Hank&amp;rft.btitle=Sci-fi+made+sexy+on+Eureka&amp;rft.date=April+25%2C+2007&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fentertainment1.sympatico.msn.ca%2FTV_Guide%2FInterviews%2FInsider%2FArticles%2F070425_ed_quinn_eureka_MH&amp;rft.pub=%27%27TV+Guide%27%27&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-117">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-117">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation web">
          Noer, Michael; David M. Ewalt, David M. (December 11, 2007).
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.forbes.com/2007/12/11/tony-stark-money-oped-books-cx_de_fict1507_1211stark.html" rel="nofollow">
           "The Forbes Fictional 15"
          </a>
          .
          <i>
           <a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">
            Forbes
           </a>
          </i>
          .
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.webcitation.org/6GcktoMN7" rel="nofollow">
           Archived
          </a>
          from the original on May 14, 2013
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved March 15, 2008
          </span>
          .
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIron+Man&amp;rft.au=David+M.+Ewalt%2C+David+M.&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Noer&amp;rft.au=Noer%2C+Michael&amp;rft.btitle=The+Forbes+Fictional+15&amp;rft.date=December+11%2C+2007&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.forbes.com%2F2007%2F12%2F11%2Ftony-stark-money-oped-books-cx_de_fict1507_1211stark.html&amp;rft.pub=%27%27Forbes%27%27&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-118">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

          <a href="#cite_ref-118">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>

          </a>

     </i>

        </sup>
       </td>

     </table>
     <p>
      <i>
       <b>
        Iron Man
       </b>
      </i>
      is a 2008 American
      <a href="/wiki/Superhero_film" title="Superhero film">
       superhero film
      </a>
      featuring the
      <a href="/wiki/Marvel_Comics" title="Marvel Comics">
       Marvel Comics
      </a>
      character
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man" title="Iron Man">
       Iron Man
      </a>
      , produced by
      <a href="/wiki/Marvel_Studios" title="Marvel Studios">
       Marvel Studios
      </a>
      and distributed by
      <a href="/wiki/Paramount_Pictures" title="Paramount Pictures">
       Paramount Pictures
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference plainlinks nourlexpansion" id="ref_1">
       <a href="#endnote_1">
        1
       </a>
      </sup>
      It is the first installment in the
      <a href="/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe" title="Marvel Cinematic Universe">
       Marvel Cinematic Universe
      </a>
      . The film was directed by
      <a href="/wiki/Jon_Favreau" title="Jon Favreau">
       Jon Favreau
      </a>
      , with a screenplay by
      <a href="/wiki/Mark_Fergus_and_Hawk_Ostby" title="Mark Fergus and Hawk Ostby">
       Mark Fergus and Hawk Ostby
      </a>
      , Art Marcum and Matt Holloway. It stars
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_Downey,_Jr." title="Robert Downey, Jr.">
       Robert Downey, Jr.
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Terrence_Howard" title="Terrence Howard">
       Terrence Howard
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Jeff_Bridges" title="Jeff Bridges">
       Jeff Bridges
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Shaun_Toub" title="Shaun Toub">
       Shaun Toub
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Gwyneth_Paltrow" title="Gwyneth Paltrow">
       Gwyneth Paltrow
      </a>
      . In
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      , Tony Stark, an industrialist and master engineer, builds a
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man%27s_armor#Live-action_films" title="Iron Man's armor">
       powered exoskeleton
      </a>
      and becomes the technologically advanced
      <a href="/wiki/Superhero" title="Superhero">
       superhero
      </a>
      Iron Man.
     </p>
     <p>
      The film had been in development since 1990 at
      <a href="/wiki/Universal_Studios" title="Universal Studios">
       Universal Pictures
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/20th_Century_Fox" title="20th Century Fox">
       20th Century Fox
      </a>
      , or
      <a href="/wiki/New_Line_Cinema" title="New Line Cinema">
       New Line Cinema
      </a>
      at various times, before
      <a href="/wiki/Marvel_Studios" title="Marvel Studios">
       Marvel Studios
      </a>
      reacquired the rights in 2006. Marvel put the project in production as its first self-financed film, with Paramount Pictures as its distributor. Favreau signed on as director, aiming for a naturalistic feel, and he chose to shoot the film primarily in California, rejecting the
      <a href="/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States" title="East Coast of the United States">
       East Coast
      </a>
      setting of the comics to differentiate the film from numerous superhero films set in New York City-esque environments. During filming, the actors were free to create their own dialogue because pre-production was focused on the story and action. Rubber and metal versions of the armors, created by
      <a href="/wiki/Stan_Winston" title="Stan Winston">
       Stan Winston
      </a>
      's company, were mixed with
      <a href="/wiki/Computer-generated_imagery" title="Computer-generated imagery">
       computer-generated imagery
      </a>
      to create the title character.
     </p>
     <p>
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      premiered in
      <a href="/wiki/Sydney" title="Sydney">
       Sydney
      </a>
      on April 14, 2008, and was released in theaters on May 2, 2008. The film was a critical and commercial success, grossing over $585.1 million, and garnering widespread critical acclaim, with Downey's performance as Tony Stark particularly praised. The
      <a href="/wiki/American_Film_Institute" title="American Film Institute">
       American Film Institute
      </a>
      selected the film as one of the ten best of the year. A sequel,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_2" title="Iron Man 2">
        Iron Man 2
       </a>
      </i>
      , was released on May 7, 2010, and another sequel,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_3" title="Iron Man 3">
        Iron Man 3
       </a>
      </i>
      , was released on May 3, 2013.
     </p>
     <p>
     </p>

         </span>
         <span class="toctext">
          Music
         </span>
        </a>
       </li>
       <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9">

       <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-16">

       <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-21">

     </div>
     <p>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Plot">
       Plot
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      Genius, billionaire,
      <a href="/wiki/Playboy_(lifestyle)" title="Playboy (lifestyle)">
       playboy
      </a>
      , and philanthropist,
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man" title="Iron Man">
       Tony Stark
      </a>
      , who has inherited the defense contractor
      <a href="/wiki/Stark_Industries" title="Stark Industries">
       Stark Industries
      </a>
      from his father, is in
      <a href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)" title="War in Afghanistan (2001–present)">
       war-torn Afghanistan
      </a>
      with his friend and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Civil-Military_Co-operation#Doctrine" title="Civil-Military Co-operation">
       military liaison
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lieutenant_Colonel" title="Lieutenant Colonel">
       Lieutenant Colonel
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/War_Machine" title="War Machine">
       James Rhodes
      </a>
      to demonstrate the new "Jericho"
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cluster_bomb" title="Cluster bomb">
       missile
      </a>
      . The convoy is ambushed and Stark is critically wounded by one of his own rocket propelled grenades. He is captured and imprisoned in a cave by the terrorist group the
      <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_(comics)#Films" title="Mandarin (comics)">
       Ten Rings
      </a>
      , and an
      <a href="/wiki/Electromagnet" title="Electromagnet">
       electromagnet
      </a>
      is grafted into his chest by fellow captive
      <a href="/wiki/Ho_Yinsen" title="Ho Yinsen">
       Yinsen
      </a>
      to keep the
      <a href="/wiki/Shrapnel_shell" title="Shrapnel shell">
       shrapnel
      </a>
      shell shards that wounded him from reaching his heart and killing him. Ten Rings leader Raza offers Stark freedom in exchange for building a Jericho missile for the group, but Tony and Yinsen agree Raza will not keep his word.
     </p>
     <p>
      Stark and Yinsen secretly build a powerful electric generator called an
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man%27s_armor#Arc_reactor" title="Iron Man's armor">
       arc reactor
      </a>
      to power Stark's electromagnet, and then begin to secretly build a
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man%27s_armor#Live-action_films" title="Iron Man's armor">
       suit of armor
      </a>
      to be powered by the reactor, and to be used to escape. Although they keep the suit hidden almost to completion, the Ten Rings attack the workshop when they discover their intentions. Yinsen sacrifices himself to divert them while the suit powers up. The armored Stark battles his way out of the cave to find the dying Yinsen, then in anger burns the Ten Rings weapons and flies away, crashing in the desert and destroying the suit. After being rescued by Rhodes, Stark returns home and announces that his company will no longer manufacture weapons.
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Monger" title="Iron Monger">
       Obadiah Stane
      </a>
      , his father's old partner and the company's manager, advises Stark that this may ruin Stark Industries and his father's legacy. In his home workshop, Stark builds an improved version of his suit, as well as a more powerful arc reactor for his chest. Personal assistant
      <a href="/wiki/Pepper_Potts" title="Pepper Potts">
       Pepper Potts
      </a>
      places the original reactor inside a small glass showcase. Though Stane requests details, Stark keeps his work to himself.
     </p>
     <p>
      At a charity event held by Stark Industries, reporter
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christine_Everhart" title="Christine Everhart">
       Christine Everhart
      </a>
      informs Stark that his company's weapons, including the Jericho, were recently delivered to the Ten Rings and are being used to attack Yinsen's home village, Gulmira. Stark also learns Stane is trying to replace him as head of the company. Enraged by these revelations, Stark dons his new armor and flies to Afghanistan, where he saves Yinsen's village. While flying home, Stark is shot at by two
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F-22_Raptor" title="F-22 Raptor">
       F-22 Raptor
      </a>
      fighter jets. He reveals his secret identity to Rhodes over the phone in an attempt to end the attack. Meanwhile, the Ten Rings gather the pieces of Stark's prototype suit and meet with Stane, who subdues Raza with a sonic device and has the rest of the group killed, before having a new suit
      <a href="/wiki/Reverse_engineering" title="Reverse engineering">
       reverse engineered
      </a>
      from the wreckage. Seeking to find any other weapons delivered to the Ten Rings, Stark sends Pepper to
      <a href="/wiki/Hacker_(computer_security)" title="Hacker (computer security)">
       hack
      </a>
      into the company computer system from Stane's office. She discovers Stane has been supplying the terrorists and hired the Ten Rings to kill Stark, but the group reneged. Potts meets with Agent
      <a href="/wiki/Phil_Coulson" title="Phil Coulson">
       Phil Coulson
      </a>
      of
      <a href="/wiki/S.H.I.E.L.D." title="S.H.I.E.L.D.">
       S.H.I.E.L.D.
      </a>
      , a
      <a href="/wiki/Counter-terrorism" title="Counter-terrorism">
       counter-terrorism
      </a>
      agency, to inform him of Stane's activities.
     </p>
     <p>
      Stane's scientists cannot duplicate Stark's arc reactor so Stane ambushes Stark at home and takes his, though Stark manages to get to his original reactor to replace the taken one. Potts and several S.H.I.E.L.D. agents attempt to arrest Stane, but he dons his suit and attacks them. Stark fights Stane, but is outmatched without his new reactor to run his suit at full capacity. Stark lures Stane atop the Stark Industries building and instructs Potts to overload the large arc reactor there. This unleashes a massive electrical surge that causes Stane and his armor to fall into the exploding reactor, killing him. The next day, at a press conference, Stark admits to being the superhero the press has dubbed "Iron Man".
     </p>
     <p>
      In a
      <a href="/wiki/Post-credits_scene" title="Post-credits scene">
       post-credits scene
      </a>
      , S.H.I.E.L.D. Director
      <a href="/wiki/Nick_Fury" title="Nick Fury">
       Nick Fury
      </a>
      visits Stark at home, telling him that Iron Man is not "the only superhero in the world", and explaining that he wants to discuss the "
      <a href="/wiki/The_Avengers_(2012_film)" title="The Avengers (2012 film)">
       Avengers Initiative
      </a>
      ".
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Cast">
       Cast
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Robert_Downey_Jr_at_Comic_Con_2007.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="650" data-file-width="520" height="213" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Robert_Downey_Jr_at_Comic_Con_2007.jpg/170px-Robert_Downey_Jr_at_Comic_Con_2007.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Robert_Downey_Jr_at_Comic_Con_2007.jpg/255px-Robert_Downey_Jr_at_Comic_Con_2007.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Robert_Downey_Jr_at_Comic_Con_2007.jpg/340px-Robert_Downey_Jr_at_Comic_Con_2007.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Robert_Downey_Jr_at_Comic_Con_2007.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Downey promoting the film at the 2007
        <a href="/wiki/San_Diego_Comic-Con_International" title="San Diego Comic-Con International">
         San Diego Comic-Con International
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Robert_Downey,_Jr." title="Robert Downey, Jr.">
        Robert Downey, Jr.
       </a>
       as
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man" title="Iron Man">
        Tony Stark / Iron Man
       </a>
       :
      </li>
     </ul>
     <dl>
      <dd>
       An
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Industrialist" title="Industrialist">
        industrialist
       </a>
       , genius inventor, and consummate playboy, he is CEO of
       <a href="/wiki/Stark_Industries" title="Stark Industries">
        Stark Industries
       </a>
       and a chief weapons manufacturer for the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._military" title="U.S. military">
        U.S. military
       </a>
       . Favreau had planned to cast a newcomer in the role,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DowneyUnknown_2-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-DowneyUnknown-2">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         2
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       but ultimately chose Downey, a fan of the comic,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DowneyUSAToday_3-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-DowneyUSAToday-3">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         3
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       because he felt the actor's past made him an appropriate choice for the part, explaing that "The best and worst moments of Robert's life have been in the public eye. He had to find an inner balance to overcome obstacles that went far beyond his career. That's Tony Stark. Robert brings a depth that goes beyond a comic book character who is having trouble in high school, or can't get the girl."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DowneyUSAToday_3-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-DowneyUSAToday-3">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         3
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       Favreau felt Downey could make Stark a "likable asshole," but also depict an authentic emotional journey once he won over the audience.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FavreauWonderCon2008_4-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FavreauWonderCon2008-4">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         4
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       Downey had an office next to Favreau during pre-production, which allowed him greater involvement in the screenwriting process.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EmpireJuly2007_5-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EmpireJuly2007-5">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         5
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       He brought a deeper sense of humor to the film not present in previous drafts of the script.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EmpireApril2008_6-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EmpireApril2008-6">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         6
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       Downey explained, "What I usually hate about these [superhero] movies [is] when suddenly the guy that you were digging turns into
       <a href="/wiki/Dudley_Do-Right" title="Dudley Do-Right">
        Dudley Do-Right
       </a>
       , and then you're supposed to buy into all his 'Let's go do some good!' That
       <a href="/wiki/Eliot_Ness" title="Eliot Ness">
        Eliot Ness
       </a>
       -in-a-cape-type thing. What was really important to me was to not have him change so much that he's unrecognizable. When someone used to be a schmuck and they're not anymore, hopefully they still have a sense of humor."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FavreauStarkQuote_7-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FavreauStarkQuote-7">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         7
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       To prepare, Downey spent five days a week
       <a href="/wiki/Weight_training" title="Weight training">
        weight training
       </a>
       and practiced martial arts to get into shape,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DowneyUSAToday_3-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-DowneyUSAToday-3">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         3
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       which he said benefited him because "it's hard not to have a personality meltdown [...] after about several hours in that suit. I'm calling up every therapeutic moment I can think of to just get through the day."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pump_8-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-pump-8">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         8
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </dd>
     </dl>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Terrence_Howard,_USAF.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1449" data-file-width="1068" height="231" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Terrence_Howard%2C_USAF.jpg/170px-Terrence_Howard%2C_USAF.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Terrence_Howard%2C_USAF.jpg/255px-Terrence_Howard%2C_USAF.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Terrence_Howard%2C_USAF.jpg/340px-Terrence_Howard%2C_USAF.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Terrence_Howard,_USAF.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Howard preparing for the role by riding an
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F-16_Fighting_Falcon" title="F-16 Fighting Falcon">
         F-16
        </a>
        flight simulator.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Terrence_Howard" title="Terrence Howard">
        Terrence Howard
       </a>
       as
       <a href="/wiki/War_Machine" title="War Machine">
        Lt. Colonel James "Rhodey" Rhodes
       </a>
       :
      </li>
     </ul>
     <dl>
      <dd>
       A friend of Stark's, and the liaison between Stark Industries and the
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Air_Force" title="United States Air Force">
        United States Air Force
       </a>
       in the department of acquisitions, specifically weapons development. Favreau cast Howard because he felt he could play
       <a href="/wiki/War_Machine" title="War Machine">
        War Machine
       </a>
       in a sequel.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-trilogy_9-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-trilogy-9">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         9
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       Howard prepared for the role by visiting
       <a href="/wiki/Nellis_Air_Force_Base" title="Nellis Air Force Base">
        Nellis Air Force Base
       </a>
       on March 16, 2007, where he ate with the pilots and observed
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/HH-60_Pave_Hawk" title="HH-60 Pave Hawk">
        HH-60 Pave Hawk
       </a>
       rescue helicopters and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F-22_Raptor" title="F-22 Raptor">
        F-22 Raptors
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HowardNellis_10-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HowardNellis-10">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         10
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       While Rhodes is roguish in the comics after he met Stark, his earlier disciplinarian character forms
       <a href="/wiki/Double_act" title="Double act">
        a dynamic
       </a>
       with Stark, and he is unsure whether or not Stark's actions are acceptable. "Rhodey is completely disgusted with the way Tony has lived his life, but at a certain point he realizes that perhaps there is a different way," Howard said. "Whose life is the right way; is it the strict military life, or the life of an independent?"
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pump_8-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-pump-8">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         8
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       Howard and his father are Iron Man fans, partly because Rhodes was one of the few black superheroes when he was a child.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RhodesFirst_11-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-RhodesFirst-11">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         11
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       He was a Downey fan since he saw him in
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Weird_Science_(film)" title="Weird Science (film)">
         Weird Science
        </a>
       </i>
       , and the two competed physically on set.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HowardCompete_12-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HowardCompete-12">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         12
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </dd>
     </dl>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Jeff_Bridges" title="Jeff Bridges">
        Jeff Bridges
       </a>
       as
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Monger" title="Iron Monger">
        Obadiah Stane
       </a>
       :
      </li>
     </ul>
     <dl>
      <dd>
       Stark's business second-in-command. Bridges read the comics as a boy and liked Favreau's modern, realistic approach. He shaved his head, something he had wanted to do for some time, and grew a beard for the role. Bridges
       <a href="/wiki/Google_(verb)" title="Google (verb)">
        googled
       </a>
       the
       <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Obadiah" title="Book of Obadiah">
        Book of Obadiah
       </a>
       , and was surprised to learn retribution is a major theme in that particular book of the Bible, something which Stane represents.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProductionNotes_13-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ProductionNotes-13">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         13
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       Many of Stane's scenes were cut out to focus more on Stark, but the writers felt Bridges's performance allowed the application of "less is more".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BridgesCut_14-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BridgesCut-14">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         14
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </dd>
     </dl>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Shaun_Toub" title="Shaun Toub">
        Shaun Toub
       </a>
       as
       <a href="/wiki/Ho_Yinsen" title="Ho Yinsen">
        Yinsen
       </a>
       :
      </li>
     </ul>
     <dl>
      <dd>
       Stark's fellow captive. In the comics, Yinsen is a Chinese physicist, but in the film, he comes from an Afghan village called Gulmira, which is one of the aspects of the modernization of the Iron Man mythos for the film.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2014)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </dd>
     </dl>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Gwyneth_Paltrow" title="Gwyneth Paltrow">
        Gwyneth Paltrow
       </a>
       as
       <a href="/wiki/Pepper_Potts" title="Pepper Potts">
        Pepper Potts
       </a>
       :
      </li>
     </ul>
     <dl>
      <dd>
       Stark's personal assistant and budding love interest. Paltrow asked Marvel to send her any comics that they would consider relevant to her understanding of the character, who she considered to be very smart, levelheaded, and grounded. She said she liked "the fact that there's a sexuality that's not blatant." Favreau wanted Potts' and Stark's relationship to be reminiscent of a 1940s comedy, something which Paltrow considered to be fun in a sexy, yet innocent way.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Paltrow_15-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Paltrow-15">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         15
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </dd>
     </dl>
     <p>
      Additionally,
      <a href="/wiki/Faran_Tahir" title="Faran Tahir">
       Faran Tahir
      </a>
      appears as Raza, the leader of the Ten Rings;
      <a href="/wiki/Paul_Bettany" title="Paul Bettany">
       Paul Bettany
      </a>
      voices
      <a href="/wiki/Edwin_Jarvis#J.A.R.V.I.S." title="Edwin Jarvis">
       J.A.R.V.I.S.
      </a>
      , Stark's personal
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence" title="Artificial Intelligence">
       AI
      </a>
      system;
      <a href="/wiki/Leslie_Bibb" title="Leslie Bibb">
       Leslie Bibb
      </a>
      portrays
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christine_Everhart" title="Christine Everhart">
       Christine Everhart
      </a>
      , a reporter for
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Vanity_Fair_(magazine)" title="Vanity Fair (magazine)">
        Vanity Fair
       </a>
      </i>
      ; and
      <a href="/wiki/Clark_Gregg" title="Clark Gregg">
       Clark Gregg
      </a>
      appears as
      <a href="/wiki/Phil_Coulson" title="Phil Coulson">
       Phil Coulson
      </a>
      , an agent of
      <a href="/wiki/S.H.I.E.L.D." title="S.H.I.E.L.D.">
       S.H.I.E.L.D.
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMEbertReview_16-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-IMEbertReview-16">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        16
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Will_Lyman" title="Will Lyman">
       Will Lyman
      </a>
      provides the voiceover during the opening award ceremony.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lyman_17-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Lyman-17">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        17
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Samuel_L._Jackson" title="Samuel L. Jackson">
       Samuel L. Jackson
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Cameo_appearance" title="Cameo appearance">
       cameos
      </a>
      as
      <a href="/wiki/Nick_Fury" title="Nick Fury">
       Nick Fury
      </a>
      , director of S.H.I.E.L.D., in a
      <a href="/wiki/Post-credits_scene" title="Post-credits scene">
       post-credits scene
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-samueljacksoncameo_18-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-samueljacksoncameo-18">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        18
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson's face was previously used as the model for that of the
      <a href="/wiki/Ultimate_Marvel" title="Ultimate Marvel">
       Ultimate Marvel
      </a>
      imprint
      <a href="/wiki/Ultimate_Nick_Fury" title="Ultimate Nick Fury">
       version of Nick Fury
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JacksonUltimate_19-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-JacksonUltimate-19">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        19
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Other cameos in the film include:
      <a href="/wiki/Stan_Lee" title="Stan Lee">
       Stan Lee
      </a>
      as himself, being mistaken for
      <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Hefner" title="Hugh Hefner">
       Hugh Hefner
      </a>
      by Stark at a party;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-StanLee_20-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-StanLee-20">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        20
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      director
      <a href="/wiki/Jon_Favreau" title="Jon Favreau">
       Jon Favreau
      </a>
      as
      <a href="/wiki/Happy_Hogan" title="Happy Hogan">
       Happy Hogan
      </a>
      , Stark's
      <a href="/wiki/Bodyguard" title="Bodyguard">
       bodyguard
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Chauffeur" title="Chauffeur">
       chauffeur
      </a>
      ;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EmpireApril2008_6-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-EmpireApril2008-6">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        6
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      [Tom Morello]], who also provides additional guitar music for the film, as a terrorist guard;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Morello_21-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Morello-21">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        21
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Jim_Cramer" title="Jim Cramer">
       Jim Cramer
      </a>
      as himself.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cramer_22-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Cramer-22">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        22
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Ghostface_Killah" title="Ghostface Killah">
       Ghostface Killah
      </a>
      had a cameo in a scene where Stark briefly stays in
      <a href="/wiki/Dubai" title="Dubai">
       Dubai
      </a>
      , but the scene was cut from the theatrical release for pacing reasons.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-depth_23-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-depth-23">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        23
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Production">
       Production
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Development">
       Development
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="quotebox" style="float: right; clear: right; margin: 0.5em 0 0.8em 1.4em; width: 33%; padding: 6px; border: 1px solid #aaa; font-size: 88%; background-color: #F9F9F9;">
      <div class="" style="position: relative; text-align: left;">
       <div>
        <p>
         "We worked with
         <a href="/wiki/Michael_Crichton" title="Michael Crichton">
          Michael Crichton
         </a>
         's researchers to find a grounded realistic way to deal with the suit. The idea was he needed the suit to stay alive. He's the same guy we used with
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Spider-Man_2" title="Spider-Man 2">
           Spider-Man 2
          </a>
         </i>
         to come up with
         <a href="/wiki/Doctor_Octopus" title="Doctor Octopus">
          Doc Ock
         </a>
         's inhibitor chips and what the arms are made of and how they work. [...]
         <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_(comics)" title="Mandarin (comics)">
          Mandarin
         </a>
         was an Indonesian terrorist who masqueraded as a rich playboy who Tony knew."
        </p>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div style="text-align: left;">
       —Alfred Gough on his draft for Nick Cassavetes' and New Line's aborted version
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GoughQuote_24-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-GoughQuote-24">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         24
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In April 1990,
      <a href="/wiki/Universal_Studios" title="Universal Studios">
       Universal Studios
      </a>
      bought the rights to develop
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      for the big screen.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Universal_25-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Universal-25">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        25
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Stuart_Gordon" title="Stuart Gordon">
       Stuart Gordon
      </a>
      was to direct a low-budget film based on the property,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pump_8-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-pump-8">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        8
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      but by February 1996,
      <a href="/wiki/20th_Century_Fox" title="20th Century Fox">
       20th Century Fox
      </a>
      had acquired the rights from Universal.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fox_26-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Fox-26">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        26
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In January 1997,
      <a href="/wiki/Nicolas_Cage" title="Nicolas Cage">
       Nicolas Cage
      </a>
      expressed interest in portraying the lead role in a potential film,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cage_27-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Cage-27">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        27
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      while in September 1998,
      <a href="/wiki/Tom_Cruise" title="Tom Cruise">
       Tom Cruise
      </a>
      had expressed interest in producing as well as starring in the film debut of Iron Man.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cruise_28-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Cruise-28">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        28
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Jeff_Vintar" title="Jeff Vintar">
       Jeff Vintar
      </a>
      and Iron Man co-creator
      <a href="/wiki/Stan_Lee" title="Stan Lee">
       Stan Lee
      </a>
      co-wrote a story for Fox, which Vintar adapted into a screenplay, and included a new science-fiction origin for the character, and featured
      <a href="/wiki/MODOK" title="MODOK">
       MODOK
      </a>
      as the villain.
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tom_Rothman" title="Tom Rothman">
       Tom Rothman
      </a>
      , President of Production at Fox, credited the screenplay with finally making him understand the character. In May 1999, Jeffrey Caine was hired to rewrite Vintar and Lee's script,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-archive_29-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-archive-29">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        29
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      while in October 1999,
      <a href="/wiki/Quentin_Tarantino" title="Quentin Tarantino">
       Quentin Tarantino
      </a>
      was approached to write and direct the film.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tarantino_30-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Tarantino-30">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        30
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Fox eventually sold the rights to
      <a href="/wiki/New_Line_Cinema" title="New Line Cinema">
       New Line Cinema
      </a>
      the following December, reasoning that although the Vintar/Lee script was strong, the studio had too many Marvel superheroes in development, and "we can't make them all."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NewLine_31-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NewLine-31">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        31
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      By July 2000, the film was being written for New Line
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NewLine2_32-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NewLine2-32">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        32
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      by
      <a href="/wiki/Ted_Elliott_(screenwriter)" title="Ted Elliott (screenwriter)">
       Ted Elliott
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Terry_Rossio" title="Terry Rossio">
       Terry Rossio
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-archive_29-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-archive-29">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        29
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Tim_McCanlies" title="Tim McCanlies">
       Tim McCanlies
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McCanliesWriting_33-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-McCanliesWriting-33">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        33
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      McCanlies's script used the idea of a
      <a href="/wiki/Nick_Fury" title="Nick Fury">
       Nick Fury
      </a>
      cameo to set up his own film.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-archive_29-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-archive-29">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        29
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In June 2001, New Line entered talks with
      <a href="/wiki/Joss_Whedon" title="Joss Whedon">
       Joss Whedon
      </a>
      , a fan of the character, to direct,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WhedonDirecting_34-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-WhedonDirecting-34">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        34
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and in December 2002, McCanlies had turned in a completed script.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McCanliesCompleted_35-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-McCanliesCompleted-35">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        35
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In December 2004, the studio attached director
      <a href="/wiki/Nick_Cassavetes" title="Nick Cassavetes">
       Nick Cassavetes
      </a>
      to the project for a target 2006 release.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cassavetes_36-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Cassavetes-36">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        36
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Screenplay drafts were written by
      <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Gough" title="Alfred Gough">
       Alfred Gough
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Miles_Millar" title="Miles Millar">
       Miles Millar
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/David_Hayter" title="David Hayter">
       David Hayter
      </a>
      , and pitted Iron Man against his father
      <a href="/wiki/Howard_Stark" title="Howard Stark">
       Howard Stark
      </a>
      , who becomes
      <a href="/wiki/War_Machine" title="War Machine">
       War Machine
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NewLineScreenplays_37-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NewLineScreenplays-37">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        37
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      After two years of unsuccessful development, and the deal with Cassavetes falling through,
      <a href="/wiki/New_Line_Cinema" title="New Line Cinema">
       New Line Cinema
      </a>
      returned the film rights to Marvel.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NewLineScreenplays_37-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-NewLineScreenplays-37">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        37
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In November 2005,
      <a href="/wiki/Marvel_Studios" title="Marvel Studios">
       Marvel Studios
      </a>
      worked to start development from scratch,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MarvelDevelopment_38-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MarvelDevelopment-38">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        38
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and announced
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      as their first independent feature, as the character was their only major one not already depicted in live action.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EmpireJuly2007_5-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-EmpireJuly2007-5">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        5
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to associate producer Jeremy Latcham, "we went after about 30 writers and they all passed", saying they were uninterested in the project due to both the relative obscurity of the character and it being a solely Marvel production. Even the rewrites when the film had a script lead to many refusals.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MCUDocumentary_39-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MCUDocumentary-39">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        39
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-production">
       Pre-production
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Len_Wiseman" title="Len Wiseman">
       Len Wiseman
      </a>
      had been in negotiations to direct,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wiseman_40-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Wiseman-40">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        40
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      before
      <a href="/wiki/Jon_Favreau" title="Jon Favreau">
       Jon Favreau
      </a>
      was hired in April 2006.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FavreauMarcumHolloway_41-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FavreauMarcumHolloway-41">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        41
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Favreau had wanted to work with Marvel producer
      <a href="/wiki/Avi_Arad" title="Avi Arad">
       Avi Arad
      </a>
      on another film after they both worked on
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Daredevil_(film)" title="Daredevil (film)">
        Daredevil
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EmpireJuly2007_5-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-EmpireJuly2007-5">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        5
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Favreau celebrated getting the job by going on a diet, and lost seventy pounds.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pump_8-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-pump-8">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        8
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The director found the opportunity to create a politically ambitious "ultimate spy movie" in
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      , citing inspiration from
      <a href="/wiki/Tom_Clancy" title="Tom Clancy">
       Tom Clancy
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/James_Bond" title="James Bond">
       James Bond
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/RoboCop" title="RoboCop">
       RoboCop
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Inspiration_42-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Inspiration-42">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        42
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Favreau described his approach as similar to an
      <a href="/wiki/Independent_film" title="Independent film">
       independent film
      </a>
      — "[i]f
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_Altman" title="Robert Altman">
       Robert Altman
      </a>
      had directed
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Superman_(1978_film)" title="Superman (1978 film)">
        Superman
       </a>
      </i>
      "
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EmpireJuly2007_5-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-EmpireJuly2007-5">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        5
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      — and also cited
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_Begins" title="Batman Begins">
        Batman Begins
       </a>
      </i>
      as an inspiration.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sauron_43-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-sauron-43">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        43
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He wanted to make
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      a story of an adult man literally reinventing himself after discovering the world is far more complex than he originally believed.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FavreauWants_44-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FavreauWants-44">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        44
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Favreau changed the
      <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">
       Vietnam War
      </a>
      origin of the character to Afghanistan, as he did not want to do a
      <a href="/wiki/Period_piece" title="Period piece">
       period piece
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-trilogy_9-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-trilogy-9">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        9
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Arthur Marcum and Matt Holloway where hired to write the script,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FavreauMarcumHolloway_41-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-FavreauMarcumHolloway-41">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        41
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      while Mark Fergus and Hawk Ostby wrote another version, with Favreau compiling both team's scripts,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FergusOstby_45-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FergusOstby-45">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        45
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/John_August" title="John August">
       John August
      </a>
      then 'polishing' the combined version.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-August_46-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-August-46">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        46
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Comic book staff
      <a href="/wiki/Mark_Millar" title="Mark Millar">
       Mark Millar
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Brian_Michael_Bendis" title="Brian Michael Bendis">
       Brian Michael Bendis
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Joe_Quesada" title="Joe Quesada">
       Joe Quesada
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Tom_Brevoort" title="Tom Brevoort">
       Tom Brevoort
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Axel_Alonso" title="Axel Alonso">
       Axel Alonso
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Macchio_(comics)" title="Ralph Macchio (comics)">
       Ralph Macchio
      </a>
      were also called upon by Favreau to give advice on the script.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thinktank_47-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-thinktank-47">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        47
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Favreau, while "trying to [make] the character of genius billionaire Tony Stark... seem real," took Robert Downey Jr.'s suggestion for a meeting with
      <a href="/wiki/Elon_Musk" title="Elon Musk">
       Elon Musk
      </a>
      , the founder of
      <a href="/wiki/SpaceX" title="SpaceX">
       SpaceX
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Tesla_Motors" title="Tesla Motors">
       Tesla
      </a>
      . Favreau felt "Downey was right", calling Musk "a paragon of enthusiasm, good humor and curiosity — a Renaissance man in an era that needs them."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Musk_48-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Musk-48">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        48
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Choosing a villain was difficult, because Favreau felt Iron Man's archnemesis, the
      <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_(comics)" title="Mandarin (comics)">
       Mandarin
      </a>
      , would not feel realistic, especially after Mark Millar gave his opinion on the script.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thinktank_47-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-thinktank-47">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        47
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He felt only in a sequel, with an altered tone, would the fantasy of the Mandarin's rings be appropriate.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mandarin_49-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-mandarin-49">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        49
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The decision to push him into the background is comparable to
      <a href="/wiki/Sauron" title="Sauron">
       Sauron
      </a>
      in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings" title="The Lord of the Rings">
        The Lord of the Rings
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sauron_43-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-sauron-43">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        43
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      or
      <a href="/wiki/Palpatine" title="Palpatine">
       Palpatine
      </a>
      in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Star_Wars" title="Star Wars">
        Star Wars
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mandarin_49-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-mandarin-49">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        49
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Favreau also wanted Iron Man to face a giant enemy. The switch from Mandarin to Obadiah Stane was done after Bridges was cast,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-depth_23-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-depth-23">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        23
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      with Stane originally intended to become a villain in the sequel.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thinktank_47-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-thinktank-47">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        47
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Crimson_Dynamo" title="Crimson Dynamo">
       Crimson Dynamo
      </a>
      was also a villain in early drafts of the script.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EmpireApril2008_6-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-EmpireApril2008-6">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        6
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Favreau felt it was important to include intentional
      <a href="/wiki/In-joke" title="In-joke">
       inside references
      </a>
      for fans of the comics, such as giving the two fighter jets that attack Iron Man the
      <a href="/wiki/Call_sign" title="Call sign">
       call signs
      </a>
      of "Whiplash 1" and "Whiplash 2," a reference to the comic book villain
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Blacklash" title="Blacklash">
       Whiplash
      </a>
      , and including
      <a href="/wiki/Captain_America" title="Captain America">
       Captain America
      </a>
      's shield in Stark's workshop.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EasterEggs_50-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EasterEggs-50">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        50
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The post-credits sequence that introduces
      <a href="/wiki/Samuel_L._Jackson" title="Samuel L. Jackson">
       Samuel L. Jackson
      </a>
      as
      <a href="/wiki/Nick_Fury" title="Nick Fury">
       Nick Fury
      </a>
      was written by comics writer
      <a href="/wiki/Brian_Michael_Bendis" title="Brian Michael Bendis">
       Brian Michael Bendis
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-samueljacksoncameo_18-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-samueljacksoncameo-18">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        18
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Filming">
       Filming
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Production was based in the former
      <a href="/wiki/Howard_Hughes" title="Howard Hughes">
       Hughes Company
      </a>
      soundstages in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Playa_Vista,_Los_Angeles,_California" title="Playa Vista, Los Angeles, California">
       Playa Vista, Los Angeles, California
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PlayaVista_51-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PlayaVista-51">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        51
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Howard_Hughes" title="Howard Hughes">
       Howard Hughes
      </a>
      was one of the inspirations for the comic book, and the filmmakers acknowledged the coincidence that they would film Iron Man creating the flying Mark III where the
      <a href="/wiki/Hughes_H-4_Hercules" title="Hughes H-4 Hercules">
       Hughes H-4 Hercules
      </a>
      was built.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProductionNotes_13-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-ProductionNotes-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Favreau rejected the
      <a href="/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States" title="East Coast of the United States">
       East Coast
      </a>
      setting of the comic books because many superhero films had already been set there.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-trilogy_9-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-trilogy-9">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        9
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Filming began on March 12, 2007,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FilmingBegins_52-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FilmingBegins-52">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        52
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      with the first few weeks spent on Stark's captivity in Afghanistan.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FirstWeeks_53-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FirstWeeks-53">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        53
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The cave where Stark is imprisoned was a 150- to 200-yard (150–200 m) long set, which had movable forks in the caverns to allow greater freedom for the film's crew.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-trilogy_9-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-trilogy-9">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        9
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Production_designer" title="Production designer">
       Production designer
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/J._Michael_Riva" title="J. Michael Riva">
       J. Michael Riva
      </a>
      saw footage of a
      <a href="/wiki/Taliban" title="Taliban">
       Taliban
      </a>
      fighter in Afghanistan, and saw the cold breath as he spoke: realizing remote caves are actually very cold, Riva placed an air conditioning system in the set. He also sought Downey's advice about makeshift objects in prison, such as a sock being used to make tea.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProductionNotes_13-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-ProductionNotes-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Afterwards, Stark's capture was filmed at
      <a href="/wiki/Lone_Pine,_California" title="Lone Pine, California">
       Lone Pine
      </a>
      , and other exterior scenes in Afghanistan were filmed at
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Olancha" title="Olancha">
       Olancha
      </a>
      Sand Dunes, where the crew endured two days of 40 to 60-mile per hour (60 to 100 km/h) winds.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProductionNotes_13-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-ProductionNotes-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Filming at
      <a href="/wiki/Edwards_Air_Force_Base" title="Edwards Air Force Base">
       Edwards Air Force Base
      </a>
      began in mid-April,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EdwardsBegins_54-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EdwardsBegins-54">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        54
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and ended on May 2.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EdwardsEnds_55-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EdwardsEnds-55">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        55
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Exterior shots of Stark's home were digitally added to footage of
      <a href="/wiki/Point_Dume" title="Point Dume">
       Point Dume
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Malibu,_California" title="Malibu, California">
       Malibu
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-depth_23-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-depth-23">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        23
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      while the interior was built at Playa Vista, where Favreau and Riva aimed to make Stark's home look less futuristic and more "
      <a class="extiw" href="//en.wiktionary.org/wiki/grease_monkey" title="wikt:grease monkey">
       grease monkey
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProductionNotes_13-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-ProductionNotes-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Filming concluded on June 25, 2007, at
      <a href="/wiki/Caesars_Palace" title="Caesars Palace">
       Caesars Palace
      </a>
      in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Las_Vegas,_Nevada" title="Las Vegas, Nevada">
       Las Vegas, Nevada
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FilmingEnds_56-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FilmingEnds-56">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        56
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Favreau, a newcomer to action films, remarked, "I'm shocked that I [was] on schedule. I thought that there were going to be many curveballs". He hired "people who are good at creating action", so "the human story [felt] like it belongs to the comic book genre".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pump_8-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-pump-8">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        8
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      There was much
      <a href="/wiki/Improvisation" title="Improvisation">
       improvisation
      </a>
