      in dialogue scenes, because the script was not completed when filming began (the filmmakers had focused on the story making sense and planning the action). Favreau acknowledged that improvisation would make the film feel more natural. Some scenes were shot with two cameras to capture lines said on the spot. Multiple takes were done, as Downey wanted to try something new each time.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-depth_23-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-depth-23">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        23
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It was Downey's idea to have Stark hold a
      <a href="/wiki/News_conference" title="News conference">
       news conference
      </a>
      on the floor,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pump_8-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-pump-8">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        8
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and he created the speech Stark makes when demonstrating the Jericho weapon.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FavreauWonderCon2008_4-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-FavreauWonderCon2008-4">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        4
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Brian_Michael_Bendis" title="Brian Michael Bendis">
       Brian Michael Bendis
      </a>
      wrote three pages of dialogue for the Nick Fury cameo scene, with the filmmakers choosing the best lines for filming.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thinktank_47-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-thinktank-47">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        47
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The cameo was filmed with a skeleton crew in order to keep it a secret, but rumors appeared on the Internet only days later. Marvel Studios's Kevin Feige subsequently had the scene removed from all preview prints in order to maintain the surprise and keep fans guessing.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CameoRemoved_57-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-CameoRemoved-57">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        57
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Post-production">
       Post-production
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ironmonger_2008film.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="450" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c7/Ironmonger_2008film.jpg/220px-Ironmonger_2008film.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c7/Ironmonger_2008film.jpg/330px-Ironmonger_2008film.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c7/Ironmonger_2008film.jpg/440px-Ironmonger_2008film.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ironmonger_2008film.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A scale model of the "Iron Monger" suit.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Favreau wanted the film to be believable by showing the construction of the suit in its three stages.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-trilogy_9-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-trilogy-9">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        9
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Stan_Winston" title="Stan Winston">
       Stan Winston
      </a>
      , a fan of the comic book, and his company built metal and rubber versions of the armors. They had previously worked on Favreau's
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Zathura_(film)" title="Zathura (film)">
        Zathura
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProductionNotes_13-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-ProductionNotes-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Favreau's main concern with the effects was whether the transition between the computer-generated and practical costumes would be too obvious.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FavreauEffectsConcerns_58-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FavreauEffectsConcerns-58">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        58
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Light_%26_Magic" title="Industrial Light &amp; Magic">
       Industrial Light &amp; Magic
      </a>
      (ILM) was hired to create the bulk of the visual effects, with additional work being completed by
      <a href="/wiki/The_Orphanage_(company)" title="The Orphanage (company)">
       The Orphanage
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/The_Embassy_Visual_Effects" title="The Embassy Visual Effects">
       The Embassy
      </a>
      ; Favreau trusted ILM after seeing
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_At_World%27s_End" title="Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End">
        Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Transformers_(film)" title="Transformers (film)">
        Transformers
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProductionNotes_13-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-ProductionNotes-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Mark I design was intended to look like it was built from spare parts. The back is less armored than the front, because Stark would use his resources for a forward attack. It also foreshadows the design of Stane's armor. A single 90-pound (41 kg) version was built, causing concern when a stuntman fell over inside it, though both the stuntman and the suit were unscathed. The armor was also designed to only have its top half worn at times.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProductionNotes_13-7">
       <a href="#cite_note-ProductionNotes-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Embassy created a digital version of the Mark I.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Embassy_59-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Embassy-59">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        59
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Stan Winston Studios built a 10-foot (3.0 m), 800-pound (360 kg) animatronic version of "
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Monger" title="Iron Monger">
       Iron Monger
      </a>
      " (Obadiah Stane),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProductionNotes_13-8">
       <a href="#cite_note-ProductionNotes-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      a name which Obadiah Stane calls Tony Stark and himself earlier in the film as a reference, but is never actually used for the suit itself in the film. The animatronic required five operators for the arm, and was built on a
      <a href="/wiki/Gimbal" title="Gimbal">
       gimbal
      </a>
      to simulate walking.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProductionNotes_13-9">
       <a href="#cite_note-ProductionNotes-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A
      <a href="/wiki/Scale_model" title="Scale model">
       scale model
      </a>
      was used for the shots of it being built.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-depth_23-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-depth-23">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        23
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The Mark II resembles an airplane prototype, with visible flaps.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-depth_23-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-depth-23">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        23
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Iron Man comic book artist
      <a href="/wiki/Adi_Granov" title="Adi Granov">
       Adi Granov
      </a>
      designed the Mark III with illustrator Phil Saunders.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GranovSaunders_60-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-GranovSaunders-60">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        60
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Granov's designs were the primary inspiration for the film's, and he came on board the film after he recognized his work on Jon Favreau's MySpace page.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sauron_43-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-sauron-43">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        43
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Saunders streamlined Granov's concept art, making it stealthier and less cartoonish in its proportions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProductionNotes_13-10">
       <a href="#cite_note-ProductionNotes-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Sometimes, Downey would only wear the helmet, sleeves and chest of the costume over a
      <a href="/wiki/Motion_capture" title="Motion capture">
       motion capture
      </a>
      suit.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProductionNotes_13-11">
       <a href="#cite_note-ProductionNotes-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      For shots of the Mark III flying, it was animated to look realistic by taking off slowly, and landing quickly. To generate shots of Iron Man and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F-22_Raptor" title="F-22 Raptor">
       F-22 Raptors
      </a>
      battling, cameras were flown in the air to provide reference for physics, wind and frost on the lenses.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MarkIIIFlying_61-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MarkIIIFlying-61">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        61
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      For further study of the physics of flying, skydivers were filmed in a vertical
      <a href="/wiki/Wind_tunnel" title="Wind tunnel">
       wind tunnel
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WindTunnel_62-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-WindTunnel-62">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        62
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Phil Saunders created
      <a href="/wiki/Concept_art" title="Concept art">
       concept art
      </a>
      for the
      <a href="/wiki/War_Machine" title="War Machine">
       War Machine
      </a>
      armor and said that it was originally intended to be used in the film but was "cut from the script about halfway through pre-production." Saunders said that the War Machine armor "was going to be called the Mark IV armor and would have had weaponized swap-out parts that would be worn over the original Mark III armor," and that it "would have been worn by Tony Stark in the final battle sequence."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WarMachine_63-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-WarMachine-63">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        63
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Music">
       Music
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_(soundtrack)" title="Iron Man (soundtrack)">
       Iron Man (soundtrack)
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Composer
      <a href="/wiki/Ramin_Djawadi" title="Ramin Djawadi">
       Ramin Djawadi
      </a>
      , an Iron Man fan who still has issues of the comic from the late 1970s, has also been into heavy metal music since the early 1990s. While he normally composes after watching an
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assembly_cut" title="Assembly cut">
       assembly cut
      </a>
      , Djawadi began work after seeing the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Teaser_trailer" title="Teaser trailer">
       teaser trailer
      </a>
      . Favreau clearly envisioned a focus on "heavy" guitar in the score, and Djawadi composed the music on that instrument before arranging it for orchestra. The composer said Downey's performance inspired the several Iron Man themes (for his different moods), as well as Stark's playboy
      <a href="/wiki/Leitmotif" title="Leitmotif">
       leitmotif
      </a>
      . Djawadi's favorite of the Iron Man themes is the "kickass" because of its "rhythmic pattern that is a hook on its own. Very much like a machine." The other themes are "not so much character based, but rather plot based that carry you through the movie".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Music_64-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Music-64">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        64
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Tom_Morello" title="Tom Morello">
       Tom Morello
      </a>
      of
      <a href="/wiki/Rage_Against_the_Machine" title="Rage Against the Machine">
       Rage Against the Machine
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Audioslave" title="Audioslave">
       Audioslave
      </a>
      , contributed additional guitar work to the film's soundtrack.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Morello_21-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Morello-21">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        21
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Release">
       Release
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      The premiere was held at the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_Union" title="Greater Union">
       Greater Union
      </a>
      theater at
      <a href="/wiki/George_Street,_Sydney" title="George Street, Sydney">
       George Street, Sydney
      </a>
      , on April 14, 2008.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Premiere_65-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Premiere-65">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        65
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The film was released in the United State on May 2, 2008,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USRelease_66-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-USRelease-66">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        66
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      while the international release was pushed up to April 30, 2008.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-InternationalRelease_67-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-InternationalRelease-67">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        67
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Marketing">
       Marketing
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Robert_Downey_Jr-2008.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3872" data-file-width="2592" height="254" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Robert_Downey_Jr-2008.JPG/170px-Robert_Downey_Jr-2008.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Robert_Downey_Jr-2008.JPG/255px-Robert_Downey_Jr-2008.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Robert_Downey_Jr-2008.JPG/340px-Robert_Downey_Jr-2008.JPG 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Robert_Downey_Jr-2008.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Downey promoting the film in
        <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">
         Mexico City
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Marvel and Paramount modeled their marketing campaign for
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      on that of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Transformers_(film)" title="Transformers (film)">
        Transformers
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transformers_68-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-transformers-68">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        68
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Sega" title="Sega">
       Sega
      </a>
      released an
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_(video_game)" title="Iron Man (video game)">
       video game
      </a>
      based on the film, which included other iterations of the character.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VideoGame_69-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-VideoGame-69">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        69
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A 30-second spot for the film aired during a
      <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLII" title="Super Bowl XLII">
       Super Bowl XLII
      </a>
      break.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SuperBowl_70-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SuperBowl-70">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        70
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      6,400
      <a href="/wiki/7-Eleven" title="7-Eleven">
       7-Eleven
      </a>
      stores in the United States helped promote the film, and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LG_Group" title="LG Group">
       LG Group
      </a>
      also made a deal with Paramount.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transformers_68-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-transformers-68">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        68
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Hasbro" title="Hasbro">
       Hasbro
      </a>
      created figures of armors from the film, as well as
      <a href="/wiki/Titanium_Man" title="Titanium Man">
       Titanium Man
      </a>
      (who appears in the video game) and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hulkbuster_Armor_MK_II" title="Hulkbuster Armor MK II">
       armor from the
       <i>
        World War Hulk
       </i>
       comics
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hasbro_71-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Hasbro-71">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        71
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Worldwide,
      <a href="/wiki/Burger_King" title="Burger King">
       Burger King
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Audi" title="Audi">
       Audi
      </a>
      promoted the film. Jon Favreau was set to direct a commercial for the fast-food chain, as
      <a href="/wiki/Michael_Bay" title="Michael Bay">
       Michael Bay
      </a>
      did for
      <i>
       Transformers
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transformers_68-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-transformers-68">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        68
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the film, Tony Stark drives an
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Audi_R8_(road_car)" title="Audi R8 (road car)">
       Audi R8
      </a>
      , and also has an "American cheeseburger" from Burger King after his rescue from Afghanistan, as part of the studio's
      <a href="/wiki/Product_placement" title="Product placement">
       product placement
      </a>
      deal with the respective companies. Three other vehicles, the
      <a href="/wiki/Audi_S6" title="Audi S6">
       Audi S6
      </a>
      sedan,
      <a href="/wiki/Audi_A5" title="Audi A5">
       Audi S5
      </a>
      sports coupe and the
      <a href="/wiki/Audi_Q7" title="Audi Q7">
       Audi Q7
      </a>
      SUV, also appear in the film.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Audi_72-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Audi-72">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        72
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reuters_73-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Reuters-73">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        73
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Audi created a tie-in website, as
      <a href="/wiki/General_Motors" title="General Motors">
       General Motors
      </a>
      did for
      <i>
       Transformers
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transformers_68-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-transformers-68">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        68
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Oracle_Corporation" title="Oracle Corporation">
       Oracle Corporation
      </a>
      also promoted the film on its site.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Oracle_74-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Oracle-74">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        74
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Several
      <a href="/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe_tie-in_comics" title="Marvel Cinematic Universe tie-in comics">
       tie-in comics
      </a>
      were released for the film.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Comics_75-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Comics-75">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        75
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Home_media">
       Home media
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      <span id="DVD">
      </span>
      <span id="Video">
      </span>
      The film was released on DVD and
      <a href="/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc" title="Blu-ray Disc">
       Blu-ray Disc
      </a>
      on September 30, 2008, in North America, and October 27, 2008 in Europe.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HomeMediaRelease_76-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-HomeMediaRelease-76">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        76
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      DVD sales were very successful, selling over 4 million copies the first week and generating a gross of over US$93 million.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TheNumbers_77-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TheNumbers-77">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        77
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rediff_78-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Rediff-78">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        78
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      There were a total of 9 million copies sold and an accumulated total sales of over $160 million (not including Blu-ray).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TheNumbers_77-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-TheNumbers-77">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        77
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      For the home releases of the film, the image on the newspaper Stark reads before he announces he is Iron Man had to be altered because of amateur photographer Ronnie Adams filing a lawsuit against Paramount and Marvel for using his on-location spy photo in the scene.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AdamsPhoto_79-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-AdamsPhoto-79">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        79
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A
      <a href="/wiki/Walmart" title="Walmart">
       Wal-Mart
      </a>
      -exclusive release included a preview of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man:_Armored_Adventures" title="Iron Man: Armored Adventures">
        Iron Man: Armored Adventures
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WalMart_80-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-WalMart-80">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        80
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The film was also collected in a 10-disc
      <a href="/wiki/Box_set" title="Box set">
       box set
      </a>
      titled
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Marvel_Cinematic_Universe_films#Home_Media" title="List of Marvel Cinematic Universe films">
        Marvel Cinematic Universe: Phase One – Avengers Assembled
       </a>
      </i>
      which includes all of the "
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Marvel_Cinematic_Universe_films#Phase_One" title="List of Marvel Cinematic Universe films">
       Phase One
      </a>
      " films in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PhaseOneSetAnnounced_81-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PhaseOneSetAnnounced-81">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        81
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It was released on April 2, 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PhaseOneSetDelayed_82-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PhaseOneSetDelayed-82">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        82
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Reception">
       Reception
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Box_office">
       Box office
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      earned $318.4 million in North America and $266.8 million in other territories, for a worldwide gross of $585.1 million.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-boxmojo_1-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-boxmojo-1">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        1
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <dl>
      <dt>
       North America
      </dt>
     </dl>
     <p>
      In its opening weekend,
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      grossed $98,618,668 in 4,105 theaters in the United States and Canada, ranking No. 1 at the box office,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mojoweek_83-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-mojoweek-83">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        83
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      giving it the eleventh biggest-opening weekend at the time,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mojoweekend_84-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-mojoweekend-84">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        84
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      ninth-widest release in terms of theaters,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mojotheaters_85-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-mojotheaters-85">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        85
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the third highest-grossing opening weekend of 2008 behind
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Kingdom_of_the_Crystal_Skull" title="Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull">
        Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_(film)" title="The Dark Knight (film)">
        The Dark Knight
       </a>
      </i>
      . It grossed $35.2 million on its first day, giving it the thirteenth biggest-opening day at the time.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mojoday_86-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-mojoday-86">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        86
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      had the second-best premiere for a non-sequel, behind
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Spider-Man_(2002_film)" title="Spider-Man (2002 film)">
        Spider-Man
       </a>
      </i>
      , and the fourth biggest-opening for a superhero film.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-forbessuperhero_87-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-forbessuperhero-87">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        87
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      was also the No. 1 film in the U.S. and Canada in its second weekend, grossing $51.1 million,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mojoweek_83-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-mojoweek-83">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        83
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      giving it the twelfth-best second weekend and the fifth-best for a non-sequel.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mojosecond_88-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-mojosecond-88">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        88
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      On June 18, 2008,
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      became that year's first film to pass the $300 million mark for the domestic box office.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mojo300_89-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-mojo300-89">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        89
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-news300_90-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-news300-90">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        90
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Critical_response">
       <span id="Critics">
       </span>
       <span id="Critical_reception">
       </span>
       Critical response
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      In May 2008,
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      was identified as the "best-reviewed film of the year so far" by Jen Yamato of review aggregator
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">
        Rotten Tomatoes
       </a>
      </i>
      , with the site reporting that at that time the film had received a rating of 95% based on 107 reviews, a rating that held its place to January 2010.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Best_91-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Best-91">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        91
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Review_aggregator" title="Review aggregator">
       review aggregator
      </a>
      website
      <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">
       Rotten Tomatoes
      </a>
      reported a 93% approval rating with an average rating of 7.6/10 based on 242 reviews. The website's consensus reads, "Director Jon Favreau and star Robert Downey make this smart, high impact superhero movie one that even non-comics fans can enjoy."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
       <a href="#cite_note-92">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        92
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">
       Metacritic
      </a>
      gave the film a
      <a href="/wiki/Standard_score" title="Standard score">
       normalized
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Weighted_mean" title="Weighted mean">
       average
      </a>
      score of 79, based on 38 reviews.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Metacritic_93-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Metacritic-93">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        93
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Among the major trade journals, Todd McCarthy of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">
        Variety
       </a>
      </i>
      called the film an "expansively entertaining special effects extravaganza" with "fresh energy and stylistic polish",
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McCarthy_94-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-McCarthy-94">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        94
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      while Kirk Honeycutt of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" title="The Hollywood Reporter">
        The Hollywood Reporter
       </a>
      </i>
      praised the film, while nonetheless finding "disappointment [in] a climatic [sic] battle between different Iron Man prototypes [...] how did Tony's nemesis learn how to use the suit?"
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Honeycutt_95-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Honeycutt-95">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        95
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In one of the first major-daily newspaper reviews,
      <a href="/wiki/Frank_Lovece" title="Frank Lovece">
       Frank Lovece
      </a>
      of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Newsday" title="Newsday">
        Newsday
       </a>
      </i>
      lauded the film's "emotional truth [...] pitch-perfect casting and plausibly rendered super-science" that made it "faithful to the source material while updating it – and recognizing what's made that material so enduring isn't just the high-tech cool of a man in a metal suit, but the human condition that got him there".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lovece_96-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Lovece-96">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        96
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/A._O._Scott" title="A. O. Scott">
       A. O. Scott
      </a>
      of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">
        The New York Times
       </a>
      </i>
      called the film "an unusually good superhero picture. Or at least – since it certainly has its problems – a superhero movie that's good in unusual ways."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott_97-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Scott-97">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        97
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Among the specialty press, Garth Franklin of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Dark_Horizons" title="Dark Horizons">
        Dark Horizons
       </a>
      </i>
      commended the "impressive sets and mechanics that combine smoothly with relatively seamless CG", and said, "Robert Downey, Jr., along with director Jon Favreau [...] help this rise above formula. The result is something that, whilst hardly original or groundbreaking, is nevertheless refreshing in its earnestness to avoid dark dramatic stylings in favor of an easy-going, crowd-pleasing action movie with a sprinkle of anti-war and redemption themes".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Franklin_98-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Franklin-98">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        98
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Among major metropolitan weeklies,
      <a href="/wiki/David_Edelstein" title="David Edelstein">
       David Edelstein
      </a>
      of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_(magazine)" title="New York (magazine)">
        New York
       </a>
      </i>
      magazine called the film "a shapely piece of mythmaking [...] Favreau doesn't go in for stylized comic-book frames, at least in the first half. He gets real with it – you'd think you were watching a military thriller",
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Edelstein_99-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Edelstein-99">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        99
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      while conversely,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/David_Denby_(film_critic)" title="David Denby (film critic)">
       David Denby
      </a>
      of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_New_Yorker" title="The New Yorker">
        The New Yorker
       </a>
      </i>
      put forth a negative review, claiming "a slightly depressed, going-through-the-motions feel to the entire show [...]
      <a href="/wiki/Gwyneth_Paltrow" title="Gwyneth Paltrow">
       Gwyneth Paltrow
      </a>
      , widening her eyes and palpitating, can't do much with an antique role as Stark's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Girl_Friday_(idiom)" title="Girl Friday (idiom)">
       girl Friday
      </a>
      , who loves him but can't say so;
      <a href="/wiki/Terrence_Howard" title="Terrence Howard">
       Terrence Howard
      </a>
      , playing a military man who chases around after Stark, looks dispirited and taken for granted".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Denby_100-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Denby-100">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        100
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/IGN" title="IGN">
        IGN
       </a>
      </i>
      <span style="padding-left:0.1em;">
       '
      </span>
      s Todd Gilchrist recognized Downey as "the best thing" in a film that "functions on autopilot, providing requisite story developments and character details to fill in this default 'origin story' while the actors successfully breathe life into their otherwise conventional roles".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gilchrist_101-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Gilchrist-101">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        101
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Looking at the sociocultural aspects of the film, Cristobal Giraldez Catalan at
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Bright_Lights_Film_Journal" title="Bright Lights Film Journal">
        Bright Lights Film Journal
       </a>
      </i>
      argues that, "
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      is far more than playboy fantasy; it is American foreign policy realized without context....
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      , with narrative and directorial precision, once again provides the high-fidelity misogyny and anti-Muslim rhetoric Hollywood is known for."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Catalan_102-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Catalan-102">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        102
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>

         Best Visual Effects
        </a>
       </td>
       <td>
        <i>
         Iron Man
        </i>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">
       Roger Ebert
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Richard_Corliss" title="Richard Corliss">
       Richard Corliss
      </a>
      named
      <i>
       Iron Man
      </i>
      as among their favorite films of 2008.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ebert_109-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ebert-109">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        109
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Corliss_110-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Corliss-110">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        110
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It was selected by the
      <a href="/wiki/American_Film_Institute" title="American Film Institute">
       American Film Institute
      </a>
      as one of the
      <a href="/wiki/American_Film_Institute_Awards_2008" title="American Film Institute Awards 2008">
       ten best films of the year
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AFIfav_111-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-AFIfav-111">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        111
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and by
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Empire_(film_magazine)" title="Empire (film magazine)">
        Empire
       </a>
      </i>
      magazine as one of
      <i>
       The 500 Greatest Movies of All Time
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Empire_112-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Empire-112">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        112
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Tony Stark was also selected by
      <i>
       Empire
      </i>
      as one of
      <i>
       The 100 Greatest Movie Characters of All Time
      </i>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EmpireTony_113-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EmpireTony-113">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        113
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and on their list of the
      <i>
       100 Greatest Fictional Characters
      </i>
      , Fandomania.com ranked him at number 37.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fandomania_114-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Fandomania-114">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        114
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Sequels">
       <span id="Sequel">
       </span>
       <span id="Sequels">
       </span>
       Sequels
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Iron_Man_2">
       <i>
        Iron Man 2
       </i>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_2" title="Iron Man 2">
       Iron Man 2
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The sequel,
      <i>
       Iron Man 2
      </i>
      , was released in the United States on May 7, 2010 with Jon Favreau and Robert Downey, Jr. returning as director and lead, respectively, with a screenplay by
      <a href="/wiki/Justin_Theroux" title="Justin Theroux">
       Justin Theroux
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Don_Cheadle" title="Don Cheadle">
       Don Cheadle
      </a>
      replaces
      <a href="/wiki/Terrence_Howard" title="Terrence Howard">
       Terrence Howard
      </a>
      in the role of Colonel Rhodes, who is also seen as
      <a href="/wiki/War_Machine" title="War Machine">
       War Machine
      </a>
      . Also starring is
      <a href="/wiki/Gwyneth_Paltrow" title="Gwyneth Paltrow">
       Gwyneth Paltrow
      </a>
      as Pepper Potts;
      <a href="/wiki/Mickey_Rourke" title="Mickey Rourke">
       Mickey Rourke
      </a>
      as villain
      <a href="/wiki/Whiplash_(comics)" title="Whiplash (comics)">
       Ivan Vanko
      </a>
      ;
      <a href="/wiki/Sam_Rockwell" title="Sam Rockwell">
       Sam Rockwell
      </a>
      as
      <a href="/wiki/Justin_Hammer" title="Justin Hammer">
       Justin Hammer
      </a>
      ;
      <a href="/wiki/Scarlett_Johansson" title="Scarlett Johansson">
       Scarlett Johansson
      </a>
      as S.H.I.E.L.D. agent
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Widow_(Natalia_Romanova)" title="Black Widow (Natalia Romanova)">
       Natasha Romanoff
      </a>
      ; and
      <a href="/wiki/Samuel_L._Jackson" title="Samuel L. Jackson">
       Samuel L. Jackson
      </a>
      as S.H.I.E.L.D. director
      <a href="/wiki/Nick_Fury" title="Nick Fury">
       Nick Fury
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Iron_Man_3">
       <i>
        Iron Man 3
       </i>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_3" title="Iron Man 3">
       Iron Man 3
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Studios_(production_company)" title="The Walt Disney Studios (production company)">
       Disney
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Marvel_Studios" title="Marvel Studios">
       Marvel Studios
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Paramount_Pictures" title="Paramount Pictures">
       Paramount Pictures
      </a>
      announced a May 3, 2013 release date for
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_3" title="Iron Man 3">
        Iron Man 3
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IM3_115-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-IM3-115">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        115
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Favreau said in December 2010 that he would not direct
      <i>
       Iron Man 3
      </i>
      , opting to direct
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Magic_Kingdom_(film)" title="Magic Kingdom (film)">
        Magic Kingdom
       </a>
      </i>
      , but reprised his role as
      <a href="/wiki/Happy_Hogan" title="Happy Hogan">
       Happy Hogan
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IM3Favreau_116-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-IM3Favreau-116">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        116
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Shane_Black" title="Shane Black">
       Shane Black
      </a>
      directed
      <i>
       Iron Man 3
      </i>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Black_117-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Black-117">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        117
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      from a screenplay by
      <a href="/wiki/Drew_Pearce" title="Drew Pearce">
       Drew Pearce
      </a>
      . Robert Downey, Jr. returned as Tony Stark, as did Gwyneth Paltrow as Pepper Potts and Don Cheadle as Colonel Rhodes, who uses the moniker
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Patriot#Iron_Patriot_II" title="Iron Patriot">
       Iron Patriot
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Guy_Pearce" title="Guy Pearce">
       Guy Pearce
      </a>
      starred as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aldrich_Killian" title="Aldrich Killian">
       Aldrich Killian
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Ben_Kingsley" title="Ben Kingsley">
       Ben Kingsley
      </a>
      as Trevor Slattery.
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">
       See also
      </span>
     </h2>

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
       Notes
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="refbegin" style="">

       <li>
        <span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_1">
         <b>
          <a href="#ref_1">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        In July 2013, the film's distribution rights were transferred from
        <a href="/wiki/Paramount_Pictures" title="Paramount Pictures">
         Paramount Pictures
        </a>
        to
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Studios_(production_company)" title="The Walt Disney Studios (production company)">
         The Walt Disney Studios
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Note_118-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-Note-118">
          <span>
           [
          </span>
          118
          <span>
           ]
          </span>
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Note2_119-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-Note2-119">
          <span>
           [
          </span>
          119
          <span>
           ]
          </span>
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Note3_120-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-Note3-120">
          <span>
           [
          </span>
          120
          <span>

          </span>
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ol>

        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation news">
          Adler, Shawn (September 30, 2008).
          <a class="external text" href="http://splashpage.mtv.com/2008/09/30/iron-man-co-writers-discuss-their-favorite-deleted-scenes-plus-an-exclusive-dvd-bonus-clip/" rel="nofollow">

             <li>
              <b>
               <img alt="Portal" data-file-height="28" data-file-width="32" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fd/Portal-puzzle.svg/16px-Portal-puzzle.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fd/Portal-puzzle.svg/24px-Portal-puzzle.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fd/Portal-puzzle.svg/32px-Portal-puzzle.svg.png 2x" width="16"/>
               <a href="/wiki/Portal:Marvel_Cinematic_Universe" title="Portal:Marvel Cinematic Universe">
                Portal
               </a>
              </b>
             </li>
            </ul>
           </div>
          </td>
         </tr>
        </table>
       </td>
      </tr>

         <tr>
          <th class="navbox-group" scope="row">
           1972–1980
          </th>
          <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px;">
           <div style="padding:0em 0.25em;">
            <ul>
             <li>
              <i>
               <a href="/wiki/Slaughterhouse-Five_(film)" title="Slaughterhouse-Five (film)">
                Slaughterhouse-Five
               </a>
              </i>
              (1972)
             </li>
             <li>
              <i>
               <a href="/wiki/Soylent_Green" title="Soylent Green">
                Soylent Green
               </a>
              </i>
              (1973)
             </li>
             <li>

        <a href="https://donate.wikimedia.org/wiki/Special:FundraiserRedirector?utm_source=donate&amp;utm_medium=sidebar&amp;utm_campaign=C13_en.wikipedia.org&amp;uselang=en" title="Support us">
